    From Seeds of Apium graveolens Linn. to a Cerebral Ischemia Medicine: The Long Journey of 3-n-Butylphthalide

    • José Marco-Contelles*
      José Marco-Contelles
      Laboratory of Medicinal Chemistry, Institute of Organic Chemistry, CSIC, Juan de la Cierva, 3, 28006-Madrid, Spain
      *Email: [email protected] (J.M-C.).
      More by José Marco-Contelles
      View Biography
      http://orcid.org/0000-0003-0690-0328
      •  and 
    • Yihua Zhang*
      Yihua Zhang
      State Key Laboratory of Natural Medicines, China Pharmaceutical University, Nanjing 210009, PR China
      Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Drug Discovery for Metabolic Diseases, China Pharmaceutical University, Nanjing 210009, PR China
      Center of Drug Discovery, China Pharmaceutical University, Nanjing 210009, PR China
      *Email: [email protected] (Y.Z.).
      More by Yihua Zhang
      View Biography
      http://orcid.org/0000-0003-2378-7064
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2020, 63, 21, 12485–12510
    Publication Date (Web):July 16, 2020

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    3-n-Butylphthalide (NBP) as well as its derivatives and analogues (NBPs), in racemic or enantiomerically pure forms, possess potent and diverse pharmacological properties and have shown a great potential therapeutic interest for many human conditions, especially for cerebral ischemia. This Perspective outlines the synthesis and therapeutic applications of NBPs.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Due to the limitations and secondary effects of recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rt-PA), the only drug in the clinics for cerebral ischemia (CI) therapy, a number of small molecules have been investigated for potential CI clinical application.
    This is the case of (S)-3-n-butylphthalide [(S)-NBP](1) (Figure 1), a natural product initially isolated from Apium graveolens Linn.,(2) a well-known herbal folk medicine of the Apiaceae family, with the strong characteristic odor of celery.(3,4)(S)-NBP was identified as a component of the resinoid of lovage root by Naves(5) and later by Mitsuhashi.(6,7)(S)-NBP was also isolated by Barton and de Vries(8) from celery oil in 1970.(9) Both enantiomers of NBP, but particularly (S)-NBP and the more easily available (RS)-NBP, have been extensively investigated for the therapy of CI, giving a mass of satisfactory results that prompted the State Food and Drug Administration of China to approve it for CI in 2002(10) and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA, US) to approve it for a phase II clinical trial for CI.
    Since the last specific review on the synthesis of (RS)-NBP in 2007 by Xiong and Li,(11) only two reviews have been published later, one by Massa et al. in 2012(12) and the second by Mal et al. in 2014, as a full account of the synthetic methodologies and applications of phthalides and phthalans but where (RS)-NBP was marginally cited.(13) The published documents(14−16) mostly focused on the neuroprotection and safety of (RS)-NBP for CI therapy. Furthermore, no review has been dedicated to summarize the increasing number of publications for the synthesis and biological activity of (RS)-NBP derivatives/analogues, such as the ring-opened NBP, 2-(1-hydroxypentyl)benzoic acid (HPBA) derivatives which have shown potential therapeutic interest.
    To fill this gap, and taking into account the pharmacological interest of NBP as well as its derivatives/analogues (NBPs) and the new synthetic methods that have been described in the last years, the present Perspective where to gather all these new results seems opportune and appropriate. First of all, we will update the recent synthetic developments of (RS)-NBP, with particular attention to the preparation of enantiomerically pure (R or S)-NBP, as the relationship between chirality and biological activity is important and has been documented.(17) Second, the biological/pharmacological activities, mechanism of action, and clinical applications of the NBPs will be shown and discussed based on the targeted pathologies for which the NBPs have been designed. Particular attention will be given obviously to CI, although NBPs seem to have great potential therapeutic interest for other human conditions.(18)

    2. 3-n-Butylphthalide (NBP)

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    2.1. Synthesis of NBP

    2.1.1. Synthesis of Racemic NBP

    Ellman et al.(19) described the very efficient Rh(III)-catalyzed reaction of methyl (Z)-N-(3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)phenyl)benzimidate and n-pentaldehyde to afford (RS)-NBP in 65% yield. Kuethe and Maloney(20) reported that the stepwise addition of i-PrMgCl/LiCl to methyl 2-iodobenzoate (1) (Figure 2) and n-pentaldehyde afforded (RS)-NBP in 82%, most possibly by a mechanism where, in the first step, the Grignard reagent promotes the formation of the iodoarylmagnesium species, followed by addition to the aldehyde and final lactonization. Prasad and Sudalai(21) showed that the reaction of 1-(2-bromophenyl)pentan-1-ol (2) (Figure 2) with sodium cyanide gave a presumed nitrile intermediate which, after cyclization, gave (RS)-NBP in excellent yield. He and Xue(22) communicated that (RS)-NBP could be prepared in two steps, in 81% overall yield, starting from 2-pentanoylbenzoic acid (3) (Figure 2) after reaction with N′,N′,N′,N′-tetramethyl-O-(N-succinimidyl)uronium tetrafluoroborate, in the presence of diisopropylethylamine, followed by catalytic hydrogenation of the intermediate (Z)-3-butylideneisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one. Sudalai and co-workers(23) described that titanium superoxide promoted the oxidative lactonization of 2-pentylbenzaldehyde (4) (Figure 2) using tert-butylhydroperoxide (TBHP) as an oxidant to give (RS)-NBP in 70% yield. Suchand and Satyanarayana(24) reported that the reaction of 2-iodobenzoate (1) with n-pentaldehyde, Pd(OAc)2, silver oxide, and TBHP gave intermediate methyl 2-pentanoylbenzoate (5) (Figure 2) and that after ketone reduction with sodium borohydride, followed by lactonization, gave (RS)-NBP. The same group also described a method(25) that was essentially the same proposed by Prasad and Sudalai,(21) starting from 1-(2-bromophenyl)pentan-1-ol (2) (Figure 2) to give (RS)-NBP in lower yield (71%), in similar harsh conditions, but without use of toxic sodium cyanide. Singh et al.(26) described the synthesis of phthalides, catalyst-free, using oxygen as a green oxidant that was used for the gram scale synthesis of racemic NBP (70% yield), in a continuous flow process, starting from 1-(o-tolyl)pentan-1-one (6) (Figure 2). Satyanarayana et al.(27) described a [Pd]-promoted coupling reaction of iodoaryl derivatives and alcohols, for the synthesis of ketones, using TBHP, which would oxidize the alcohols yielding in situ acyl radicals, the key reactive species for the final acylation reaction leading to the ketones. This method was applied to methyl 2-iodobenzoate (1) (Figure 2) and n-pentaldehyde to give (RS)-NBP in 45% overall yield, obtained by reducing the crude intermediate ketoester with NaBH4 and lactonization. This methodology is essentially the same adopted by the group described before;(24) the only difference consisted of the starting materials, that were alcohols instead of aldehydes. Hadizadeh and co-workers(28) reported the synthesis of racemic NBP by reacting 2-formylbenzoic acid with n-butylmagnesium bromide, followed by aqueous acid workup, an identical method to the approach already described.(29) More novel, but also simple and efficient, was the protocol where the Grignard reagent of 1-(2-bromophenyl)pentan-1-ol (2) (Figure 2) was reacted with carbon dioxide to provide the corresponding acid that in the acidic workup afforded (RS)-NBP.(28)

    2.1.2. Synthesis of Enantiomerically Pure NBP

    Cheng et al.(30) reported the cobalt complexes-promoted addition of o-iodobenzoates to aldehydes followed by lactonization, a method applied to the chiral synthesis of phthalides derived from n-butyraldehyde and n-heptaldehyde. Zhang et al.(31) described the asymmetric synthesis of NBP using isomannide or isosorbide (IS) as chiral auxiliaries. Isomannide was transformed into (3R,6R)-6-(benzyloxy)hexahydrofuro[3,2-b]furan-3-yl 2-formylbenzoate (7) (Figure 3), which, after reaction with n-BuMgBr, followed by sequential treatment with KOH and dilute HCl, gave pure (S)-NBP. A similar protocol, but starting from IS, afforded pure (R)-NBP.
    Hu et al.(32) resolved (RS)-NBP by sequential treatment with NaOH and HCl to give 2-(1-hydroxypentyl)benzoic acid (8), whose reaction with (−)-(S)-α-phenylethylamine [(S)-9] gave diastereomerically pure salt 10 which, after reaction with NaOH and HCl, afforded enantiomerically pure (S)-NBP (Scheme 1). Similarly, the reaction of racemic intermediate 8 with (+)-(R)-α-phenylethylamine [(R)-9] gave diastereomerically pure salt 11 that led to enantiomerically pure (R)-NBP (Scheme 1). This is a very simple but efficient method to get enantiomerically pure NBPs that was later applied to the synthesis of enantiomerically pure HPBA derivatives.(33) The Novozyme 435-mediated enzymatic resolution of racemic NBP has been investigated,(34,35) and optimized conditions have been found to produce (S)-2-(1-acetoxypentyl)-benzenecarboxylic acid and (R)-3-n-butylphthalide, in enantiomerically pure forms.(36,37) Dong and co-workers(38) reported a very efficient chiral rhodium-catalyzed ketone hydroacylation method that was applied to the synthesis of (S)-NBP, starting from 2-pentanoylbenzaldehyde (12) (Figure 3). Zhang et al.(39) reported the reaction of ethyl 2-pentanoylbenzoate (13) (Figure 3) with [Ru(p-cymene)Cl]2-N-((1S,2S)-2-amino-1,2-bis(3,5-di-tert-butylphenyl)ethyl)-4-methylbenzenesulfonamide, in the presence of sodium formate and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide, to give (S)-NBP (61%). Duan and co-workers(40) prepared (S)-NBP in a three-step process, in 66% overall yield, starting from methyl 2-formylbenzoate, after aldol-lactonization reaction with n-butanone, using (2R)-N-((2R)-1-hydroxy-4-methyl-1-phenyl-1-(l2-phosphaneyl)pentan-2-yl)pyrrolidine-2-carboxamide, to give enantiomerically pure (S)-3-(2-oxobutyl)isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (14) (Figure 3), followed by thioacetalization and desulfurization. Oguro and Watanabe(41) described the synthesis and sensory evaluation of (RS)-, (R)-, and (S)-NBP prepared by intramolecular Diels–Alder reaction of racemic or enantiomerically pure 1-ethynylpentyl 2,4-pentadienoate (15) (Figure 3) as the minor compound in a mixture where the major component was sedanenolide, a phthalide natural product, isolated in 1977 from the essential oil of celery.(42)(S)-NBP was found to be superior to (R)-NBP in odor and sensory properties.(41) Ghorai and co-workers(43) described the organocatalyzed intramolecular oxa-Michael reaction of in situ formed peroxy hemiacetals, as an efficient method for the synthesis of chiral lactones, that was applied to the formal total synthesis of (R)-NBP. The reaction of (E)-2-(3-oxobut-1-en-1-yl)benzaldehyde (16) (Figure 4) with TBHP, in the presence of 3-((3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)phenyl)amino)-4-(((S)-(6-methoxyquinolin-4-yl)((1S,2S,4S,5R)-5-vinylbicyclo[2.2.2]octan-2-yl)methyl)amino)cyclobut-3-ene-1,2-dione as catalyst, gave (R)-3-(2-oxobutyl)isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one in 58% yield that could be eventually transformed into (R)-NBP.(40) Zhang and co-workers(44) reported the enantioselective tandem [RuCl(benzene)(S)-SunPhos]Cl catalyzed hydrogenation/lactonization of 2-acylarylcarboxylates, a method that was applied to the synthesis of (S)-NBP, using as precursor methyl 2-pentanoylbenzoate (5) (Figure 2) which is very similar to the approach described by Zhang.(39) Ge et al.(45) reported that the complex of iridium with a spiro-[4,4]-1,6-nonadiene-based phosphine-oxazoline ligand catalyzed the chiral hydrogenation of 3-ylidenephthalides to afford chiral 3-substituted phthalides in enantiomerically pure form, applying the method to intermediate (Z)-3-butylideneisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (NBP1) (Figure 4) for the synthesis of (R)-NBP.
    To sum up, a number of methods have been proposed for the synthesis of NBP, in racemic or high enantiomeric excess, a key point in its therapeutic development in view of the relationship between chirality and biological activity.
    NBP has a diverse and rich pharmacology owing to the in vitro and in vivo appropriate experiments targeted for the investigation of its therapeutic applications in a large number of pathologies that we will detail in the next sections.

    2.2. General Therapeutical Applications of NBP and Its Enantiomers

    2.2.1. Asthma

    The potential therapeutic effect of (RS)-NBP for asthma has been explored in BALB/c mice treated with ovalbumin (OVA).(46) The results showed that (RS)-NBP remarkably lowered the OVA-caused rise in inflammation scoring, goblet cell percentage and mucus secretion of airway tissue, enhanced pulmonary function, decreased interleukins IL-4, -8, and -13, and tumor necrosis factor (TNFα) in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid and total immunogloblin E (IgE) and OVA-specific IgE in serum, suggesting that (RS)-NBP can mitigate airway inflammation and mucus hypersecretion in asthma by modulating nuclear factor- κB (NF-κB) activation.(46)

    2.2.2. Depression(47)

    Wang and co-workers have investigated(48) the effect of (RS)-NBP in a model of depression, observing that the drug reduces stress-promoted social deficits, anxiety-like and despair manifestation, altering metabolite levels of glycolysis and tricarboxylic acid cycle components.

    2.2.3. Diabetes

    The effect of NBP on diabetes has been seldom explored. In a patent submitted by Wang and co-workers,(49) the authors claimed that some selected phthalides, NBP among them, showed high sugar attenuating effects in mamals, thus being possible efficient compounds for the therapy of diabetes mellitus. More recently, Xu et al.(50) reported that NBP alleviated high glucose-mediated damage to Schwann cells and found that the underlying mechanism consists of inhibition of nitration stress and apoptosis, concluding that the compound is a neuroprotective agent for diabetic peripheral neuropathy. Conversely, diabetes mellitus is linked to rapid cognitive impairment, as several studies have confirmed.(51−53) For instance, a study by Li et al.,(53) aimed at investigating the protection given by (S)-NBP on cognition in a rat model of type 1 diabetes, using the Morris water maze (MWM) test, described that the escape latency was highly enhanced and the number of crossing platforms was notably reduced in the diabetic control group as compared to the normal control group, concluding that (S)-NBP can ameliorate the cognitive function by upregulating the expression of N-methyl-d-aspartate receptor subunit 2R in streptozotocin diabetic rats.

    2.2.4. Spinal Cord Injury(54−57)

    Wang and co-workers(58) found that (RS)-NBP treatment significantly reduced the motor dysfunction and neuronal apoptosis induced by spinal cord injury (SCI), inhibited the pro-inflammatory cytokine release after SCI, facilitated macrophage/microglia M2 (anti-inflammatory) polarization, and inhibited M1 (pro-inflammatory) polarization after SCI.

    2.2.5. Traumatic Brain Injury(59,60)

    Based on the well-known neuroprotective effect of (RS)-NBP, Wu et al.(61) investigated the molecular mechanism of racemic NBP against traumatic brain injury (TBI), reporting that (RS)-NBP enhanced locomotor functional recovery after TBI by preventing the activation of autophagy as well as blocking the junction protein loss and neuronal apoptosis.

    2.2.6. Epilepsy

    In a pilocarpine-generated chronic epileptic mouse model, Ye et al.(62) found that the drug reduced seizure severity and abnormal electroencephalogram and recovered cognitive and emotional deficits in epileptic mice, the plausible mechanism being the neuroprotective role of (S)-NBP attenuating neuronal loss and improving the expression of neural synaptic proteins.

    2.2.7. Carbon Monoxide Poisoning(63−66)

    Poisoning by carbon monoxide (CO) causes frequent cases of death and may result in cognitive deficit. Based on the established neuroprotective capacity of (RS)-NBP, Li et al. have investigated it for brain injury therapy after severe CO poisoning.(67) They observed that CO increased the amounts of Bcl-2 mRNA and Bax mRNA expressions and decreased mitochondrial membrane potential (MMP) of cells. (RS)-NBP maintained the high MMP, remarkably upregulated Bcl-2 mRNA, and downregulated Bax mRNA expression, and the ratio of Bcl-2 mRNA/Bax mRNA expressions was greater than that in the CO poisoning group. As the CO poisoning might promote oxidative stress (OS), the expressions of Kelch-like ECH-linked protein1 (Keap1), nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2 (Nrf-2), and quinone oxidoreductase 1 (NQO-1) proteins were analyzed, being notably augmented at 1, 3, and 7 d after drug administration as compared with the CO poisoning group. These results confirm that (RS)-NBP may protect mitochondrial function and balance the expressions of antiapoptosis genes and pro-apoptosis genes as a result of the activation of the Keap1-Nrf-2/antioxidant response element (ARE) signaling pathway.(67)

    2.2.8. Demyelination(68,69)

    Remyelination is a major restoration mechanism occurring after stroke-caused white matter damage but often breaks down due to the absence of recapture of the oligodendrocyte progenitor cells (OPCs) to the demyelinated area and the insufficient disparity of OPCs. The administration of (RS)-NBP did not raise the numbers of neuron/glia type 2-positive and oligodendrocyte lineage transcription factor 2-positive cells in the subventricular zone but promoted differentiation as well as maturation of OPCs in perilesional white matter and increased the length of crossing corticospinal tract fibers into the denervated hemispheres. These results might be associated with the enhanced expression amount of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) and the attenuated expression of neurite outgrowth inhibitor in the perilesional area in the (RS)-NBP group. These results show the effects of (RS)-NBP in the remyelination process and suggest it as a potential therapy for CI.(70)

    2.2.9. Heart Failure(71)

    Although (RS)-NBP is a known cardioprotective agent for severe myocardial infarction (MI), its chronic results on ventricular function, remodeling, and arrhythmias in the post-MI stage have not been investigated. Post-MI rats treated with the ligand showed improved cardiac function, by inhibition of the severity of ventricular arrhythmias, reduction of the cardiac index, fibrosis, hypertrophy, enhanced protein expression, distribution of Cx43 gap junction, and upregulation of the PI3k/protein kinase B (Akt)/Nrf2 pathway and the downstream ARE, including heme oxygenase-1 (HO)-1, glutathione (GSH), and Cu–Zn and Fe/Mn superoxide dismutase (SOD). These effects prove that (RS)-NBP enhances left ventricular (LV) function and diminishes ventricular arrhythmias by mitigating LV fibrosis, hypertrophy, and Cx43 gap junction remodeling.(72)

    2.2.10. Myositis, an Autoinmune Disease(73,74)

    An in vivo myosin immunization experiment was carried out to assess whether (RS)-NBP can preserve muscle cells from OS, lipid peroxidation, and apoptosis. After drug administration, increased SOD, catalase, and reduced malondialdehyde (MDA) activities were observed, directly protecting muscle mitochondria and muscle cells from oxidative damage (OD). Furthermore, (RS)-NBP increased ATPase activity in muscle mitochondrial and muscle fiber membranes, attenuated the number of apoptotic cells, and differentially regulated the Bcl-2, Bax, BAD mRNA, and protein expression amount in muscle tissues. These effects suggest that (RS)-NBP may be an efficient therapeutic agent for myopathy.(75)

    2.2.11. Parkinson’s Disease(76−80)

    Huang et al.(81) found that (RS)-NBP reduced the cytotoxicity of 1-methyl-4-phenylpyridinium ion by eliminating the mitochondrial permeability transition, lowering OS, and augmenting the cellular GSH content, also reducing the deposition of α-synuclein, thus suggesting that the drug is an attractive agent for Parkinson’s disease (PD) therapy. Wang et al.(82) explored the results of (RS)-NBP in rotenone models of PD and found that the drug increased cell viability by reducing nuclear fragmentation, conserving mitochondrial membrane potential, and diminishing reactive oxygen species (ROS) damage. In vivo treatment with (RS)-NBP enhanced apomorphine-evoked rotations and relieved dopaminergic cells.

    2.2.12. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)(83)

    Cui and co-workers(84) examined the activity of (RS)-NBP in Tg(SOD1-G93A) transgenic mice, a known model of ALS, observing that the drug notably enhanced motor performance, prolonged the survival interval, reduced motor neuron loss, and retarded motor unit reduction as compared to controls.

    2.2.13. Methamphetamine-Induced Neurotoxicity

    The investigation of the therapeutic potential of (RS)-NBP in the improvement and avoidance of methamphetamine (Meth)-caused neural damage showed that the drug reduced Meth-linked cell damage and apoptosis via blockage of Meth-induced upregulation of intracellular ROS formation and blockage of Meth-promoted reduction of split caspase-3/caspase-3 and Bcl-2/Bax ratios.(85)

    2.2.14. Alzheimer’s Disease (AD)(86−91)

    Peng et al.(90) showed that (S)-NBP protected against Aβ-mediated neurodegeneration and cognitive deficit in a rat model. beta-Amyloid (Aβ) or vehicle infusion started on day 0. Aβ-infused rats were administered 10 or 30 mg/kg (S)-NBP orally once a day for 17 successive days beginning on day 1. Vehicle-infused rats got vegetable oil only. As shown in Figure 5, no significant neuronal changes were observed in brains from vehicle-infused rats, except neuronal loss, neuronal shrinkage, and dark staining of neurons with hematoxylin–eosin staining was observed in the CA1 area of hippocampus and in cortex, after Aβ1–40 infusion. However, treatment with (S)-NBP reduced these effects by inhibiting the neuronal apoptosis induced by Aβ1–40 (Figure 5). The present results show that enantiomerically pure (S)-NBP is a neuroprotective agent against Aβ-induced neurodegeneration and cognitive deficit in an in vivo AD model, and in consequence, it may be considered as a potential drug for AD patients. Xiang and co-workers(92) studied the influence of (S)-NBP on memory damage and the expression of brain neurotrophic derived factor (BNDF), kinaseB (TrkB), phosphatidylinositol 3 kinase (Pl3K), and Akt in APP/PS1 double transgenic mouse models, observing that the drug reversed memory deficit in APP/PS1 transgenic mice and BDNF/TrkB/Pl3K/AKT was required in this process. Peng et al.(93) investigated the activity of (S)-NBP on learning and memory in a triple-transgenic AD mouse model (3xTg-AD), observing that the treatment improved learning deficits, long-term spatial memory as compared with vehicle control treatment, lowered total cerebral Aβ plaque accumulation, and reduced Aβ amounts in brain homogenates but had no effect on fibrillary Aβ plaques, confirming preferential elimination of diffuse Aβ aggregations. It was also observed that (S)-NBP significantly increased soluble amyloid precursor protein secretion (αAPPs), α-secretase, and PKCα expression but had no effect on steady-state full-length APP. Thus, it was suggested that (S)-NBP may modulate APP processing toward a nonamyloidogenic pathway and prevent Aβ deposition in the 3xTg-AD mice. Additionally, 3xTg-AD mice treated with (S)-NBP also showed reduction of glial activation and OS as compared with the control group. Wang et al.(94) demonstrated that (RS)-NBP prevented Aβ-mediated activation of astrocytes and the upregulation of pro-inflammatory products and eliminated Aβ-mediated IκBα degradation and NF-κB translocation.

    2.2.15. Vascular Dementia(95−99)

    Wang’s group studied for the first time whether (S)-NBP could be beneficial for vascular dementia (VaD) therapy,(100) showing that the drug was effective in the prevention of neuropathological alterations, due to its higher capacity to inhibit OD and increase acetylcholine synthesis.(100)

    2.2.16. Chronic Cerebral Hypoperfusion(101,102)

    Wei and co-workers(103) investigated the activity of (RS)-NBP in hypoperfused rats using the MWM test and observed that the drug significantly improved learning and memory. The amounts and aggregation of matrix metalloproteinase (MMP) and Aβ1–40 were determined by Western blot analysis and immunohistochemistry in the cerebral cortex and hippocampus, showing that the use of (RS)-NBP inhibited the hypoperfusion-mediated augmentation in Aβ1–40 and MMP-2. Min and co-workers investigated the potential of (RS)-NBP on chronic intermittent hypoxia hypercapnia (CIHH)-induced cognitive deficits, using the MWM test, and showed that the drug was particularly efficient in the navigation test, by activating BDNF and phosphorylated cAMP response element binding protein (CREB), both responsible for neuroprotection.(104)
    Being relevant to all the previous analyses and potential therapeutic applications of NBPs, it is, however, in CI where this drug has found its most important, safe, and efficient clinical use until today. In the next section, we will show and present the key aspects of its pharmaceutical/biological properties.

    2.3. Stroke: Biological Activities of NBP and Its Enantiomers

    The efficacy of NBPs to treat CI is owing to its diverse pharmacological profile, including the following:

    2.3.1. Inhibition of in Vitro Platelet Aggregation(105)

    The platelet aggregation inhibitory activity of a number of racemic or enantiomerically pure n-alkylphthalides has been reported, showing that, among them, the most potent was (S)-NBP [IE50 (μmol L–1) [induced by adenosine diphosphate (ADP)] = 94.72; [induced by arachidonic acid (AA)] = 13.25] followed by (RS)-NBP [IE50 (μmol L–1) (induced by ADP) = 169.96; (induced by AA) = 14.49, and (R)-NBP [IE50 (μmol L−) (induced by ADP) = 193.06; (induced by AA) = 16.12], in this order, comparing very well with the values found for aspirin (Asp) [IE50 (μmol L–1) (induced by ADP) = 117.94; (induced by AA) = 12.3], used as standard. The authors also observed that among the six synthesized phthalides by modifying the length of the linear chain at C3, from n = 2–7, (RS)-NBP was the most potent.(32)

    2.3.2. Protection against Hypertensive Nephropathy

    Zhu et al. analyzed the activity of (RS)-NBP on hypertensive nephropathy and the underlying mechanism of this disease in spontaneously hypertensive rats, showing that the drug effectively reduced the evolution of hypertensive nephropathy by reduction of the urinary albumin excretion and blood urea nitrogen levels, reduced blood pressure and the presence of glomerulosclerosis, attenuated tubular impairment, and reduced OS and the expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines as well as TGF-β1 in kidney tissues.(106)

    2.3.3. Neuroprotection(14,107−116)

    Zhao and co-workers observed that (RS)-NBP protected against diffuse brain damage by enhancing microcirculation disorder and lowering cerebral edema.(117)
    Yang and co-workers(118) found that pretreatment with NBP strongly reduced the number of cells with abnormal nuclear morphology induced by OGD-caused damage of newborn rat brain microvascular endothelial cells (BMECs) by upregulating Bcl-2 expression and downregulating caspase-3 expression though the hypoxia inducible factor-1α (HIF-1α) pathway. To examine the effect of (RS)-NBP on OGD-injured BMECs, cell viability was evaluated by 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) (Figure 6). These results suggest that promoting angiogenesis was possibly a new therapeutic approach to address and improve CI outcome that deserves further investigation and a deep analysis.(118)
    Administration of (S)-NBP prior to Αβ25–35 toxic insult, inducing neuronal death/apoptosis in rat hippocampal neurons and human neuroblastoma SH-SY5Y cells, increased cell viability and reduced apoptosis.(119)

    2.3.4. Reduction of the Oxidative Damage/Stress(120−124)

    The ability of (RS)-NBP to protect from the OD, enhancing antioxidant responses, has been investigated in CI animal models, showing a compelling reduction of MDA levels in brain tissues of rats.(125) The protection provided by (RS)-NBP against H2O2-caused cell inhibition was measured in cultured rBMSCs by MTT analysis (Figure 7).(126) The results showed that viability of rBMSCs was significantly lowered in the H2O2 group, whereas administration of (RS)-NBP at doses 1, 10, and 100 μmol/L increased the cell viability, compared to the H2O2 group (Figure 7B), being dose dependent. The authors clearly showed that NBP protection of rBMSCs against H2O2-induced apoptosis takes place via the PI3KAkt pathway. In addition, it was suggested that the use of NBP plus cell replacement therapy (CRT) could be a novel and useful strategy to improve cell survival in CRT for CI.(126)

    2.3.5. Reduction of Apoptosis(127−133)

    Peng et al. studied the neuroprotection provided by (S)-NBP on H2O2-mediated apoptosis in human neuroblastoma SK-N-SH cells, observing that the drug reversed the reduction of cell viability and the amounts of apoptotic-like cells. In addition, (S)-NBP treatment (10 μM) inhibited H2O2-caused downregulation of Bcl-2, Bcl-w, and PKCα but reduced the overexpression of Bax.(134) Wang et al. analyzed the role of (S)-NBP on cardiac protection in in vivo ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) models, showing that the drug improved cardiac hemodynamic function, by lowering cardiac infarct areas and apoptotic cell numbers in the peri-infarct areas.(135) Lei et al. evaluated the neuroprotection provided by (RS)-NBP on Aβ25–35-caused neuronal damage and the mechanism in the human neuroblastoma SH-SY5Y cells, showing that the drug reduced Aβ25–35-mediated cell death and neuronal apoptosis, prevented Aβ25–35-caused mitochondrial dysfunction, partially reversed the increase of Aβ25–35-caused active caspases-3 and -9, cytochrome C expressions, and the downregulation of antiapoptosis protein Bcl-2, and significantly prevented the activations of p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase and the c-Jun N-terminal kinase/stress-activated protein kinase signaling pathway.(136) Li et al.(137) observed that in adult male 129S2/sv mice, subjected to permanent middle cerebral artery occlusion (pMCAO), (RS)-NBP lowered ischemia-caused infarct formation and caspases-3 and -9 activation in the ischemic brain, reduced the TUNEL-positive cells, mitochondrial discharge of cytochrome c, and apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF) in the penumbra region, and downregulated the pro-apoptotic signaling caused by phospho-JNK and p38 expression.

    2.3.6. Neurogenesis(138−141)

    Yan and co-workers reported that (S)-NBP improved behavioral outcome of CI by initiating neurogenesis and neuroplasticity, most possibly by activation of CREB and Akt, preventing the signal transduction and activating transcription 3.(142)

    2.3.7. Regulation of NrF2(143,144)

    Zhao et al.(145) explored the capacity of (RS)-NBP for the protection of blood-brain barrier (BBB) of mice in experimental CI and the underlying mechanism of action, observing that the drug improved cognitive deficits, reduced the infarct volume, edema, and permeability of BBBs of mice, downregulated the expression of MMP-9, upregulated the expression of claudin-5 in brain tissues, and increased the expressions of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and GFAP, the ultrastructure in capillary endothelial cells of BBBs, and the expressions of Nrf-2 and HO-1.
    As shown in Figure 8, the neurologic function deficit score in the CI group was greater than in the sham group, indicating that pMCAO causes cognitive deficits. Compared with the CI group, the neurologic function deficit score in the (RS)-NBP group was reduced. The volume of CI was determined by 2,3,5-triphenyltetrazolium chloride (TTC) staining (Figure 8B), showing that compared with the CI group, the infarct volume in the (RS)-NBP group was notably reduced. The water content of brain tissues was determined by the wet and dry weight method, confirming that the water content of brain tissues on the infarcted side in the CI group was significantly increased, whereas the water content of brain tissues in the (RS)-NBP group was markedly decreased at 24 h after operation (Figure 8C). Furthermore, NBP improved the neurologic deficit scores, reduced edema and permeability of the BBBs of animals, and downregulated the expression of MMP-9. The underlying mechanism has been investigated, the results suggesting that NBP might protect BBB by activating the Nrf-2/HO-1 signaling path.(145)

    2.3.8. Potassium Channel TREK-1(146)

    Ji et al. analyzed the effects of (S)-NBP on the TREK-1 channel expressed in hamster ovary cells, using whole-cell patch-clamp to register TREK-1 channel currents. The results showed that the drug hampered TREK-1 currents in a concentration-dependent way, being more potent than (R)-NBP or (RS)-NBP.(147)

    2.3.9. Attenuation of Inflammation

    Zhao et al.(148) explored the immune modulatory activity of (S)-NBP on pro-inflammatory cytokines and microglia activation in brain tissue initiated by systemic lipopolysaccharide (LPS) administration in C57BL/6 mice, showing that systemic LPS treatment produced microglia activation in the brain and (S)-NBP administration remarkably reduced the expression of proinflammatory cytokines, such as TNFα, interleukins-1β, -6, and -10, decreasing the morphological activation of microglia. (S)-NBP inhibited the phosphorylation of the JNK MAP kinase-signaling pathway and upregulated the expression of HO-1.

    2.3.10. Autophagy(149,150)

    Xu et al. examined the activity of (S)-NBP on the cognitive deficit caused by repeated CI/IR (RCIIR) in mice, showing that the drug reduced the induced cognitive deficits in learning and memory and that the pathologic injuries in the hippocampal CA1 region were less serious in animals administered with (S)-NBP. (S)-NBP lowered the LC3-II/LC3-I ratio, inhibited autophagy, and reduced hippocampal levels of beclin-1 mRNA, suppressing autophagy. These results hint that (S)-NBP attenuation of cognitive impairment in mice after RCIIR may cause activation of Akt/target of rapamycin (mTOR) signaling and regulation of the expressions of proteins related to autophagy.(151)

    2.3.11. Inhibition of NLRP3 Inflammasome

    Treatment with (RS)-NBP could suppress thioredoxin-interacting protein-nucleotide binding oligomerization domainlike receptor family, pyrin domain containing 3 (TXNIP-NLRP3) interaction and inhibit NOD-like receptor protein 3 (NLRP3) inflammasome activation via upregulating Nrf2.(152)

    2.3.12. Angiogenesis(153−156)

    Liu and co-workers revealed that (RS)-NBP prevented cold-induced CI via improvement of cerebral microvessels.(157) Liao et al. showed that, after ischemic stroke, (RS)-NBP rescued brain tissue by increasing angiogenesis linked to upregulation of VEGF and HIF-1α expressions.(158)

    2.3.13. Metabolism

    Diao et al.(159) found that (RS)-NBP is well absorbed and analyzed its metabolism in humans following oral administration. The authors identified the enzymes responsible (alcohol dehydrogenase, aldehyde dehydrogenase, and CYP450s) for the metabolism and the formed major metabolites (10-keto-NBP, 3-OH-NBP, 10-OH-NBP, and NBP-11-oic acid) before (RS)-NBP clearance, in human urine and plasma. Very surprisingly, these metabolites do not result from aromatic ring transformation but from alkyl side chain hydroxylation, oxidation, and conjugation, their pharmacokinetic and safety profile being a motif of concern due to their increased plasma exposition.(159)
    To sum up and to highlight the strong neuroprotective power of (RS)-NBP (Figure 9),(112) it has been demonstrated that the drug protects against OGD-induced OS, mitochondrial damage, and cell death. The protection is linked to its augmentation on OGD-induced HIF-1α expression,(160) which could reduce brain edema and the expression of Rho A around the infarction and protect BBB.(161) In addition, (S)-NBP reduces spatial learning deficits and memory impairment in a MWM test, after chronic CI.(162)
    These and other investigations reported in the last 4 years(163−174) confirmed the efficient infarct volume reduction by (RS)-NBP (Figure 10)(173) or (S)-NBP (Figure 11)(169) administration after CI injury. The therapeutic activity of (RS)-NBP on stroke and its mechanism were investigated in mice submitted to 60 min MCAO,(173) as shown in Figure 10A. The values clearly showed that compared to vehicle control, (RS)-NBP notably decreased neurological impairment and the infarct volume on days 1 and 3 after MCAO (Figure 10B–D). In this work, it was demonstrated that NBP directly regulates endothelial cell activation and preserves tight junction after CI. In addition, NBP protects in vitro brain microvascular endothelial cells against OGD. Finally, it was observed that NBP decreases the infiltration of myeloid cells after CI. All together these results mean that agent NBP ameliorates cerebral circulation via decoupling the invading immune cells and reduces CI injury via restriction of neurovascular inflammation.(173)
    As shown in Figure 11, treatment with (S)-NBP (14 mg/kg/day)(169) via caudal vein immediately after reperfusion and analysis of the infarct volume at 1 and 3 d after MCAO showed a reduction of the cerebral infarct volume at 1 d after MCAO reperfusion, albeit the difference was not important (Figure 11a, p = 0.11). However, a relevant decrease in cerebral infarct volume was observed at 3 d after MCAO reperfusion (Figure 11b, p < 0.05). These results pointed out that NBP administration reduced ischemic brain injury and promoted rescue of neurological functions in early phase after CI, most possibly by skewing M1 microglia/macrophages polarization toward M2 phenotype. The authors confirmed then that NBP is an efficient drug for stroke therapy.(169)
    These results prompted the analysis of the drug in diverse clinical trials,(175,176) such as those described by Zhang and co-workers,(177) who investigated (RS)-NBP for treating transient ischemic attack, showing that the incidence of cerebral infarction in the experimental group was notably lower than in the control group (p < 0.5), concluding that (RS)-NBP could be helpful and safe. Cui and co-workers(178) reported a randomized, double-blind, double-dummy clinical trial on 573 patients within 48 h of onset of stroke, to determine the efficacy and safety of (RS)-NBP with a continuous dose regimen among patients with severe stroke, concluding that the 90-d administration with (RS)-NBP might ameliorate injuries at the third month after stroke and that the drug was safe.
    However, and despite these advantages, clinical applications of (RS)-NBP have been hampered by low aqueous solubility and poor bioavailability.(179) In addition, to improve its therapeutic effects, (RS)-NBP must be administered in combination with antioxidant and antiplatelet drugs.(180) Drug safety investigations have also shown that (RS)-NBP has side effects, such as liver dysfunction, with alterations in the levels of alanine aminotransferase and aspartate aminotransferase.(175)
    Consequently, the interesting, diverse pharmacological properties of (RS)-NBP, but also its significant drawbacks, have been the starting point for designing NBP derivatives and analogues to improve its pharmacokinetic profile for better therapeutic applications. From the biological point of view, we will show how these NBPs are endowed with a diverse array of pharmacological properties, surpassing NBP itself and making them multitarget small molecules(181) of wide potential therapeutic interest.

    3. Synthesis and Biological Activity of NBP Derivatives/Analogues

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Basically, there are three types of known NBP derivatives/analogues: the first group formed by NBP derivatives with diverse substituents at the aromatic ring (I, Figure 12); the second group formed by those where the oxygen has been replaced by a nitrogen or a sulfur atom resulting in compounds of type IIa and IIb, respectively (Figure 12); and finally, the ring-opened NBP group or hydroxypentyl benzoic acid (HPBA) derivatives III (Figure 12).

    3.1. Synthesis and Biological Activity of NBP Derivatives with Substituents at the Aromatic Ring (I)

    Wang and co-workers synthesized some racemic NBP derivatives bearing only one halogen atom (Cl, Br, or F) at positions of C4–7 on the aromatic ring (Scheme 2).(182) For the synthesis of the monosubstituted NBPs at C4–6 (Ia–c), the precursors were the corresponding anilines IVa–c transformed according to the protocol depicted in Scheme 2. Thus, treating compounds IVa–c with HBF4/NaNO2, HCl/NaNO2/CuCl, or HBr/NaNO2/CuBr gave halides Va, Vb, or Vcvia the corresponding diazonium salts, followed by halide nucleophilic displacement. Next, reaction of molecules Va–c with NBS/CCl4, followed by treatment with water, afforded 2-formylbenzoic acids VIa–c that after treatment with n-butylmagnesium bromide, followed by lactonization, gave the expected derivatives Ia–c. For the synthesis of molecules NBP2-4 bearing F, Cl, or Br at C7 (Figure 13), different synthetic approaches were applied depending on the halide.(182) In the same publication,(182) the authors reported the in vitro relaxation effects of these compounds by a rat thoracic aorta ring test and norepinephrine-caused contractile responses of an isolated rat thoracic aorta ring test. The work concluded that 3-butyl-6-fluoroisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (F-NBP, Figure 13), 6-bromo-3-butylisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (Br-NBP, Figure 13), and (RS)-NBP had vasorelaxant effects, and F-NBP and Br-NBP were more active than (RS)-NBP. In addition, in a mouse severe toxicity experiment, by intraperitoneal injection, the LD50 value of Br-NBP (>1000 mg/kg) was higher than those of F-NBP (750.89 mg/kg) and (RS)-NBP (592.93 mg/kg).(182) These results were not surprising as the selective substitution of a hydrogen by more electron withdrawing fluorine(s) or bromine(s) changes the pharmacology of biologically active molecules without increasing toxicity.(183−185)
    Gao et al.(186) described the protection provided by Br-NBP on H2O2-caused damage in PC12 cells, showing that treating with Br-NBP, before adding H2O2, enhanced cell survival and effects of GSH peroxidase and MMP, reducing the levels in the leakage of lactate dehydrogenase, MDA content, nitric oxide (NO) production, intracellular ROS, intracellular Ca2+ concentration, and cell apoptosis.
    Xu et al.(187) also observed that F-NBP reduced H2O2-caused damage in PC12 cells, reversing all the toxic actions induced by H2O2, preventing thus OD. The same group(188) studied the activity of F-NBP on the glutamate-promoted toxicity in PC12 cells, showing that the ligand prevented the injury produced by glutamate in a dose-dependent manner and was more potent than (RS)-NBP, enhancing cell viability and MMP and reducing the levels of ROS, the activity of NO synthase, apoptosis rate, and intracellular accumulation of calcium.
    In a Chinese patent, Guo et al.(189) described that 6-amino-3-n-butylphthalide (NH2-NBP) (Figure 13) inhibited the platelet aggregation, reduced the cerebral infarct volume, improved mitochondrial function, reduced OD, and neuronal apoptosis, showing stronger potency than (RS)-NBP in the same tests. These effects are in excellent accord with the biological activity described for C6 substituted 3-n-butylphthalides, such as F- or Br-NBP.(186−188)
    NO is a messenger species showing a number of physiological important functions, such as dilatation of blood vessels and immune responses, potentiating the synaptic transmission.(190,191) Therefore, appropriate increasing NO release becomes a therapeutic strategy for designing agents to treat CI.(192) With these precedents in mind, Wang and co-workers(193) designed a series of NO-donating products NH2-NBPs of type VII (Figure 14) as potential antiplatelet agents and prepared them from readily available (RS)-NBP. The in vitro inhibitory activity of the synthesized molecules on ADP-caused platelet aggregation in rabbit platelet rich plasma was next examined. Among the new compounds, 3-((1-butyl-3-oxo-1,3-dihydroisobenzofuran-5-yl)amino)-3-oxopropyl nitrate (NBP5) (Figure 14) showed significant inhibitory effects (30.42%), superior to NH2-NBP (Figure 13) (18.43%), (RS)-NBP (15.72%), and ticlopidine (Ticlid) (26.45%) under the same conditions, being almost 2-fold more potent than NH2-NBP and (RS)-NBP. It was also observed that NBP5 liberated modest amounts of NO, which could be of interest for enhancing cardiovascular and cerebral circulation. Finally, and extremely important, NBP5 was more soluble in water than the parent (RS)-NBP. In summary, these pharmacological and physicochemical properties made NBP5 a new hit-antiplatelet drug for the potential therapy of thrombosis-related CI.(193)
    (RS)-NBP may provide a therapeutic effect on AD by addressing diverse biological targets, as it has been demonstrated that the drug improves cognitive function in rats treated with Aβ peptide(87,90) and protects against cognitive impairment in VaD.(81,99) Luo et al.(18) described a number of phthalide alkyl tertiary amines as potent and selective acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitors. The newly designed ligands VIII (Figure 15) are hybrids from (RS)-NBP and donepezil (Aricept), a current clinically used AChE inhibitor (AChEI) for mild-to-moderate AD cases.(194) The synthesis of compound VIII(18) is shown in Scheme 3. O-Methylation of vanillin (17) afforded 3,4-dimethoxybenzaldehyde (18) that after oxidation gave 3,4-dimethoxybenzoic acid (19), whose reaction with 37% HCHO and HCl resulted in 5,6-dimethoxy-2-benzofuran-1(3H)-one (20) that after radical promoted bromination (NBS, AIBN) provided 3-bromo-5,6-dimethoxyisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (21), followed by treatment with triphenylphosphine to afford the triphenylphosphonium bromide 22. Next, Wittig reaction of salt 22 with aminoalkylaldehydes 23a,b led to isomers Z-(VIIIa) and E-(VIIIb) that were separated by flash chromatography, and their structures were unequivocally assigned by NMR spectroscopy. Finally, catalytic hydrogenation of the mixture Z-(VIIIa) + E-(VIIIb) gave racemic compounds VIIIc in good overall chemical yield.
    Compounds were tested in diverse pharmacological tools, including the inhibition of ChE, monoamine oxidases (MAO), and self-induced Aβ1–42 aggregation, antioxidant activity, analysis of their drug-likeness profile, in vitro BBB permeability, and step-down passive avoidance behavior. Among the evaluated NBPs, (Z)-3-(6-(benzyl(methyl)amino)hexylidene)-5,6-dimethoxyisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (NBP6) (Figure 15) was the most potent AChEI, showing a value (IC50 = 2.66 nM) better than that exhibited by donepezil (IC50 = 26.4 nM). NBP6 showed very good BBB permeability in vitro and notably reversed scopolamine-caused memory impairment in mice, concluding that agent NBP6 could be a promising AChEI for further development.
    It is interesting to highlight that in this series, no enantiomerically pure NBP derivatives were synthesized and evaluated, being still to examine the effect of chirality on the biological behavior of the NBP derivatives with substituents at the aromatic ring and to compare with (R)- and (S)-NBP activities.

    3.2. Synthesis and Biological Activity of NBP Analogues with the Oxygen Replaced by a Substituted Nitrogen or Sulfur Atom

    3.2.1. Synthesis and Biological Activity of NBP Analogues with the Oxygen Replaced by a Substituted Nitrogen Atom (IIa)

    The first report on the synthesis and biological activity of NBP analogues where the oxygen has been replaced by a substituted nitrogen (IIa) (Figure 12) was published by Lan et al.(195) In this communication, the authors designed nine 3-alkyl-2,3-dihydro-1H(alkyl)-isoindol-1-ones (Figure 16), by incorporating R1 (hydrogen, methyl, or ethyl group) to the nitrogen atom and with R2 (diverse n- or i-alkyl) as substituents at C3. The rational for this design was based on previous studies showing that isoindolinones exhibit a good activity in treating neurodegenerative diseases.(196) Then, as their structures are very similar to NBP, and the γ-lactam is more stable than the γ-lactone of NBP in physiological conditions, it was quite reasonable to hypothesize that 3-alkyl-2,3-dihydro-1H-isoindol-1-ones may possibly show improved anti-ischemic activity than NBP. The pharmacological studies involved the in vitro antiplatelet aggregation, in vivo antithrombosis, the anti-CI in transient or pMCAO rats, ROS trapping in HT22 cells, and the in vivo free radical-scavenging activities. Among evaluated NBPs, n-butyl-2,3-dihydro-1H-isoindol-1-one (NBII)(195) (Figure 16) showed the best inhibitory activity on ADP- or AA-caused platelet aggregation, being stronger than (RS)-NBP and comparable with Asp and edaravone (Eda) (Figure 1). In addition, NBII showed a potent capacity for trapping ROS, improved the survival of HT22 cells against the ROS-induced toxicity in vitro, and strongly reduced the I/R-caused OD in ischemic rat brains. Furthermore, NBII could decrease infarct size and cerebral damage, as well as improve cognitive deficits. In addition, NBII was highly bioavailable and quickly reached brain tissue keeping high plasma drug concentration, being a promising hit-agent for CI therapy.(195) However, enantiomerically pure NBIIs have not been prepared and evaluated yet, and this analysis is still pending investigation.

    3.2.2. Synthesis and Biological Activity of NBP Analogues with the Oxygen Replaced by a Sulfur Atom (IIb)

    The rationale behind the design of NBP analogues with the oxygen replaced by a sulfur atom (IIb) (Figure 12) recognizes that many drugs containing sulfur exhibit a better efficacy especially as antioxidants, ROS scavengers, and neuroprotective agents.(197,198) Thus, as envisaged, a novel class of compounds has been designed and synthesized by bioisosteric replacement of the oxygen with sulfur, incorporating 3-n-alkyl groups of different lengths, with the hope that the new ligands could prevent thrombosis and OS, being more active than NBP.
    The first communication on this topic was published by Wu et al.(199) The new NBP analogues IIb (Figure 17) were synthesized by substituting C3 with an alkyl chain of different lengths from ethyl to n-heptyl or benzyl. With these compounds in hand, the pharmacological analysis started by measuring the in vitro antiplatelet effect, in vivo antithrombotic activity in rats, ROS trapping activity in PC12 cells, antioxidant effect, and anticerebral ischemic activity in rats, including decrease of infarct size and brain-water content, as well as the reduction of cerebral damage. From the results, 3-n-pentylbenzo[c]thiophen-1(3H)-one (5d or NPBT) (Figure 17) was identified as the most potent molecule that inhibited ADP or AA-mediated in vitro platelet aggregation, better than Asp, (RS)-NBP, and Eda (Figure 1), exhibiting more potent antithrombotic and ROS trapping activities than all of them, showing stronger or similar neuroprotection against I/R in rats by improving neurobehavioral roles, decreasing infarct size and brain-water content, reducing cerebral injury, and normalizing the presence of oxidative enzymes.
    Ling et al.(200) reported that 5d showed increased ROS trapping and antiplatelet and antithrombotic activities and prevented neuroprotective effects against nervous damage caused by I/R, identifying the underlying mechanism, most possibly via the Akt/Nrf2/NOX4 signaling pathway. Compound 5d exerted better properties than (RS)-NBP (Figure 1) as follows: (a) “...Treatment with5d(90.3%) orNBP(80.5%) at 10 μM significantly attenuated oxygen glucose deprivation (OGD)/R-induced cell death...”;(200) (b) “...The addition of5dorNBPresulted in a significant attenuation of this effect (ROS generation). Moreover, at the dosage of 10 μM, the effect of5dwas superior to that of NBP...”;(200) (c) “...Nevertheless, the antioxidant effect of5dwas superior to that of NBP.”(200)
    Zhou et al.(201) proposed that the observed neuroprotection by NPBT may be due to augmented CK2 activity, that would block I/R-mediated dissociation between CK2α and Rac1, decrease NADPH oxidase activity, and inhibit ROS formation, confirming thus that the molecule could be a candidate for further development for CI therapy.
    Jian and co-workers(202) efficiently synthesized both enantiomers (R)-NPBT and (S)-NPBT and submitted them to biological evaluation by comparing with (R)- and (S)-NBP. It was observed that (S)-NBP was superior to (R)-NBP in the inhibition of platelet aggregation, infarct size and brain water content, in the improvement of neurobehavioral deficit, and in the reduction of OD and brain cortex injury. Racemic NPBT and its enantiomers inhibited in vitro ADP- or AA-mediated platelet aggregation and reduced I/R-related brain cortex damage in rats, being better than (S)-NBP. (RS)-NPBT and its enantiomers strongly lowered the infarct size in rat brains in an extent similar to (S)-NBP. Furthermore, (RS)-NPBT and its enantiomers reduced the amounts of MDA, GSH, and SOD in H2O2-treated PC12 cells and I/R-caused rats more efficiently than Eda and (S)-NBP, concluding that (RS)-NPBT and its enantiomers may be better antioxidant agents. In spite that (R)-NPBT was slightly superior to (S)-NPBT in the neuprotection from brain cortex injury in rats, both enantiomers showed similar potency as (RS)-NPBT regarding antiplatelet aggregation, antioxidation, reduction of infarct size and brain water content, and cognitive deficits.(202)
    Fang et al.(203) described the synthesis and biological evaluation of 20 three racemic NBPs of type IIb (Figure 18). Among them, eight bear the 3-hydroxy-3-methylbenzo[c]thiophen-1(3H)-one scaffold, and 15 are benzo[c]thiophen-1(3H)-ones, unsubstituted or bearing a single chlorine atom at C4, C5, or C7. In Figure 18, those highlighted in red were synthesized in this communication for the first time, while the others had been previously described(199) and prepared following the same synthetic protocol.(203) Compounds were evaluated in vitro as platelet aggregation inhibitors and for their neuroprotective capacity against hydrogen peroxide in SH-SY5Y and PC12 cells. Among them, NBP7–10 (Figure 18) were the most interesting. It was observed that 5-chloro-3-ethylbenzo[c]thiophen-1(3H)-one (NBP7) remarkably inhibited platelet aggregation caused by AA, comparable to Eda. 3-Butyl-3-hydroxybenzo[c]thiophen-1(3H)-one (NBP8) increased the relative SH-SY5Y cells survival rate, comparable to Asp. Similarly, NBP8 and 4-chloro-3-ethylbenzo[c]thiophen-1(3H)-one (NBP9) enhanced the relative cell survival rate, comparable to Eda. NBP8, NBP9, and 5-chloro-3-hydroxy-3-propylbenzo[c]thiophen-1(3H)-one (NBP10) increased PC12 cells survival rate, comparable to Eda. To sum up, we can conclude that (a) a C-3 ethyl or propyl was beneficial for the activity; (b) a hydroxyl group at C3 lowered the original activity and caused the structural instability; and (c) a Cl on the benzene ring, regardless of its location, had no effect on the biological activity.
    HPBA derivatives of type III (Figure 12) have been intensively investigated among all the NBP derivatives/analogues, and their synthesis and biological profile will be shown in the next section.

    3.3. Synthesis and Biological Activity of Ring-Opened NBP (HPBA) Derivatives (III)

    3.3.1. HPBA

    Zhang et al.(204) reported that racemic 2-(1-hydroxypentyl)benzoic acid (HPBA) (Figure 19), the most simple ring-opened derivative of NBP, reduced platelet aggregation caused by ADP or AA in a dose-dependent manner, the inhibitory power being identical to (RS)-NBP and Asp. The same group(205) described that HPBA reduced the infarct volume and improved the behavioral impairment in a rat model of transient MCAO (tMCAO), the neuronal score or the cerebral blood flow values being highly improved, compared to vehicle control. In this study,(205) it was also shown that at the highest concentration, the power of HPBA was close to (RS)-NBP, and HPBA was very quickly transformed into (RS)-NBP in blood in vitro. All these results confirmed that HPBA is an orally antiplatelet and antithrombotic drug that may be useful for the profylaxis/prevention of CI. Unfortunately, the resolution of (RS)-HPBA or asymmetric synthesis of both enantiomers and their respective biological properties have not yet been reported.

    3.3.2. PHPB

    Racemic potassium salt of 2-(1-hydroxy-n-pentyl)benzoate (PHPB) (Figure 19), currently in phase II–III clinical trials, is more soluble in water than (RS)-NBP.(206,207) Zhao and co-workers(206) investigated the activity of PHPB on the cognitive impairment caused by chronic cerebral hypoperfusion, showing that the drug highly enhanced the spatial learning and memory. Similarly, PHPB and (RS)-NBP decreased OD and lowered lipid peroxide and astrocyte activation in the cortex of the hypoperfused rats, indicating that the prevention of the neuropathological alterations and inflammation might be responsible for the observed beneficial effects of PHPB on hypoperfusion-induced cognitive impairment.(206) In a recent work, Li et al.(207) examined the in vitro and in vivo pharmacokinetic properties of racemic PHPB, concluding that PHPB is a pro-drug, whose conversion to (RS)-NBP is pH- and Ca2+-dependent, and paraoxonase enzyme is responsible for this conversion in rat plasma.(207) No resolution of (RS)-PHPB or asymmetric synthesis of both enantiomers and their respective biological properties has been reported.

    3.3.3. Brozopine (BZP)

    Based on previous studies of 6-bromo-3-butylisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (Br-NBP, Figure 13) showing its anti-H2O2-mediated injury in PC12 cells and antiplatelet aggregation effects, being however difficult to manage due to its low water-solubility, Tian and co-workers prepared racemic sodium 5-bromo-2-(α-hydroxypentyl) benzoate (BZP, Brozopine)(208) (Figure 19) and investigated the conversion of BZP into Br-NBPin vitro and in vivo and its pharmacokinetic profile as a key guide for further preclinical research and clinical trials.(209) Gao et al.(210) explored the ability of BZP and Br-NBP to lower cerebral infarction volume in the focal CI-reperfusion damage and avoid permanent global brain ischemia, proving that BZP could be more potent and safe than Br-NBP, in part due to the ability of BZP to inhibit the mitochondrial apoptotic pathways and improve the neuroplasticity. The same group examined the neuroprotection of BZP in a rat model of global CI, confirming that the drug could be very efficient for the therapy/prevention of global CI, and the observed neuroprotection would be most possibly due to the inhibition of apoptosis and the activation of the neuronal survival-signaling-pathway.(211) Xiao et al.(212) investigated the cardioprotection of BZP on I/R damage, in drug-pretreated C57BL/6 and ICR mice, finding that the drug diminished the infarct size, enhanced cardiac contractile function, and protected the heart from chronic myocardium I/R related cardiac damage. Wang and co-workers(213) analyzed the role of BZP in the pressure overload-mediated cardiac hypertrophy and heart collapse, observing that the drug ameliorated cardiomyocyte hypertrophy and excessive autophagy, as well as AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK), promoted activation of the mammalian TOR pathway probably playing a role in regulation of autophagy by BZP. The authors showed that BZP might protect the heart from pressure overload-induced hypertrophy and dysfunction, and this effect was linked to the inhibition of maladaptive cardiomyocyte autophagy via the AMPK-mTOR signaling pathway.(213) The same group explored the mechanisms of protection of BZP against CI in vitro and in vivo, concluding that BZP protects against CI via inhibition of 15-lipoxygenase-2 (15-LOX-2) activity.(214)
    In addition, the protection of BZP on focal cerebral I/R damage was examined at various concentrations in terms of the neurobehavioral score, cerebral infarction volume, and cerebral swelling in MCAO rats (ischemia for 2 h, reperfusion for 24 h). As shown in Figure 20, BZP treatment remarkably lowered the cerebral infarct volume as compared with the model group. However, BZP treatment did not protect against ischemia-reperfusion injury. In addition, the model group showed severe brain swelling, while BZP treatment reduced it. To sum up, these results demonstrated that BZP improved in vitro and in vivo focal cerebral I/R injury after sodium dithionite administration, in a dose/concentration-dependent manner by inhibiting the formation of 15-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid and expression of NF-kB, IL-6, TNF-α, and intercellular cell adhesion molecule-1. In other words, BZP exerted protective effects against CI by inhibiting 15-LOX-2 activity.(214)
    As previously described for HPBA derivatives, no resolution of racemic BZP or asymmetric synthesis of both BZP enantiomers and, consequently, their respective biological properties has been reported.
    Zhang’s group developed a number of HPBAs as potential anti-ischemic agents, able to release NO, H2S, or both NO + H2S, by appropriate functionalization of the target ligands, including suitable pharmacophores, NO donors (nitrates), and H2S donor [5-(4-hydroxyphenyl)-3H-1,2-dithiole-3-thione] to accomplish these biological tasks.

    3.3.4. ZJM-289

    This is the case of racemic HPBA derivatives of type IIIa (Figure 21), designed on the hypothesis that they may be hydrolyzed in vivo into NBP, ferulic acid, and NO, in the hope that the three compounds may synergistically display activity on the platelet and the central nervous system, showing better activity than NBP and Asp.(215)
    Among compounds of type IIIa, racemic (E)-2-[1-(diethylaminoacetoxy)pentyl]benzoic acid {2-methoxy-4-[2-(4-nitrooxybutoxycarbonyl)-vinyl]}phenyl ester hydrochloride (RS)-(ZJM-289)(215) (Figure 21) is of particular interest, whose synthesis is shown in Scheme 4. The basic hydrolysis of (RS)-NBP followed by acidification provided HPBA which was reacted with ClCH2COCl, without isolation in the presence of trimethylamine, and N,N′-dimethylaminopyridine, to afford 2-(1-(2-chloroacetoxy)pentyl)benzoic acid (24) whose coupling with 4-(nitrooxy)butyl (E)-3-(4-hydroxy-3-methoxyphenyl)acrylate (25) gave intermediate 26 that produced the target ligand, after reaction with diethylamine.(215)
    (RS)-(ZJM-289) showed stronger antithrombotic activity than (RS)-NBP and Asp in rats and protected against collagen and adrenaline-induced thrombosis in mice, confirming that NO-releasing (RS)-NBP derivatives could possess potent antiplatelet aggregation and antithrombotic effects. These results prompted Zhang and co-workers to synthesize both enantiomers of ZJM-289,(33) describing that (S)- and (R)-ZJM-289 were almost as effective as (RS)-ZJM-289(216) in inhibiting in vitro platelet aggregation and in vivo thrombus formation. Furthermore, like (RS)-ZJM-289, its enantiomers could regulate the ratio of thromboxane B2 and 6-keto-prostaglandin F1α and increase the amounts of NO, cAMP, and cGMP, confirming that the antiplatelet and antithrombotic effects of (RS)-ZJM-289 and its enantiomers are linked to both the AA cascade and the cGMP–NO signal pathway. It was also observed that treatment with (RS)-ZJM-289 and its enantiomers for 3 d highly lowered the infarct volume size, brain water content, and cognitive deficits in rats after CI reperfusion. Very interestingly, both enantiomers similarly enhanced blood flow in the stroke model and regulated endothelial function via releasing modest amounts of NO, which might contribute, to some extent, to the neuroprotection. In subsequent publications from the same group,(217,218) it was described that (S)-ZJM-289 behaved as a better neuroprotective agent than racemic ZJM-289, particularly at low doses, by enhancing mitochondrial function, avoiding mitochondria dependent cell death, and favoring survival signals.(217)
    The strong neuroprotection of (S)-ZJM-289 was confirmed in the histological and functional amelioration after MCAO experiment (Figure 22). TTC staining demonstrated that sham-operated rats had no histological proof for infarction. The noticed infarctions in vehicle, (S)-ZJM-289, and (RS)-NBP treated animals required both the cortical and subcortical areas (Figure 22A). Injuries produced by 2 h of ischemia and 3 d of reperfusion consisted of an infarct area of 30.0 ± 6.4%. (S)-ZJM-289 and (RS)-NBP notably lowered infarct size as compared to the vehicle group (Figure 22B). Neurological impairment was analyzed for 3 d after reperfusion (Figure 22C). The sham-operated animals displayed an unimpaired conduct. Vehicle-treated rats exhibited high neurological impairment throughout testing. At 48 and 72 h after reperfusion, neurological scores were remarkably diminished in (S)-ZJM-289 and (RS)-NBP-treated groups, in good agreement with infarct size determinations. From these results, it seems that in a CI experiment (S)-ZJM-289 is a more potent neuroprotective agent than NBP, mainly at lower concentrations, which may be owing to the synergistic and combined action of NBP and NO. In conclusion, compound (S)-ZJM-289 might be a very promising alternative to NBP for preventing stroke.(217)
    Similarly, (S)-ZJM-289 preconditioning promoted a late phase neuroprotection against cerebral I/R and protected cultured cortical neurons from OGD/R mediated damage. Neuroprotection of (S)-ZJM-289 preconditioning is mostly due to the translocation of Nrf2 to the nucleus, followed by the upregulation of endogenous antioxidant systems, the regulation of ERK, and JNK phosphorylation.(218)

    3.3.5. H2S-Releasing HPBA Derivatives (NBP11)

    Simultaneously, Zhang and co-workers(219) designed, synthesized, and evaluated H2S-releasing HPBA derivatives of type IIIb (Figure 23). The most promising racemic BNP11 (Figure 23) inhibited ADP or AA-mediated platelet aggregation in vitro, being superior to (RS)-NBP and Asp, and slowly released modest amounts of H2S, which could be beneficial for enhancing cardiovascular and cerebral circulation, protecting against collagen and adrenaline caused thrombosis in mice, and exhibiting stronger antithrombotic activity than (RS)-NBP and Asp in rats.(219) The same group(220) has described that NBP11 (Figure 23) notably decreased sensorimotor impairments, focal infarction, brain edema, and neural apoptosis at 72 h after tMCAO. The authors also found that NPB11 regulated the formation of superoxide and the expression of NOX2 subunits p47phox, and the upstream PI3K/AKT signaling was all downregulated, both in the penumbral region of the rat brain and in the primary cultured microglia under OGD conditions.(220)

    3.3.6. H2S/NO-Releasing HPBA Derivatives (NBP12/13)

    Looking for new and more potent antistroke drugs than (RS)-NBP, Zhang’s group has published two reports on racemic HPBA derivatives of type IIIc,d (Figure 24) designed by combining both H2S- and NO-releasing moieties in only one molecule, with the expectation of getting more potency, diverse, and complementary biological actvities.(221,105)
    Among all the synthesized ligands, IIIc(221) of ferulic type (Figure 24), (±)-(E)-2-methoxy-4-(3-(2-(nitrooxy)ethoxy)-3-oxoprop-1-en-1-yl)phenyl 2-(1-(2-(4-(5-(4-(3-thioxo-3H-1,2-dithiol-5-yl)phenoxy)pentyl)piperazin-1-yl)acetoxy)pentyl) benzoate (NBP12) (Figure 24), was the most interesting and more potent than (RS)-NBP in inhibiting the ADP-mediated platelet aggregation in vitro. Furthermore, compound NBP12 provided modest amounts of NO and SH2, beneficial for enhancing cardiovascular and cerebral circulation. Very interestingly, in a tMCAO model, oral administration with NBP12 enhanced neurobehavioral function, diminished the infarct brain size and brain water content, and increased the amounts of brain antioxidant SOD, GSH, and GSH-Px but reduced the level of oxidant MDA.(221)
    Among the enantiomerically pure ligands of type IIId, the most attractive compound was (S)-6-(4-(3-thioxo-3H-1,2-dithiol-5-yl)phenoxy)hexyl 2-(1-(2-(4-(nitrooxy)piperidin-1-yl)acetoxy)pentyl)benzoate (NBP13)(105) (Figure 24), which was the most potent inhibitor of AA- or ADP-caused platelet aggregation in vitro, being 3.8- and 7.0-fold more effective than (S)-NBP, respectively. Furthermore, NBP13 liberated modest amounts of NO and SH2, beneficial for enhancing cardiovascular and cerebral circulation.

    3.3.7. Sugar-Containing HPBA Derivatives

    Finally, it is worth mentioning the HPBA derivatives that Zhang’s group has proposed by incorporating sugar-containing structural motifs, such as IS(222) and d-glucose,(223) in order to improve the efficiency and physicochemical properties of racemic or enantiomerically pure NBP derivatives. As shown in Figure 25, NBP14(222) and NBP15(223) were the two most attractive ligands analyzed in each family of NBP.
    Many derivatives of IS showed potent vasodilation and anti-inflammatory activity.(224) Therefore, the authors hypothesized that hybridization of ring-opened NBP with IS should be more potent against CI. Among the new compounds, (3R,3aR,6S,6aR)-hexahydrofuro[3,2-b]furan-3,6-diylbis(2-((S)-1-(2-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)acetoxy)pentyl)benzoate) (NBP14) (Figure 25) displayed the strongest in vitro effect for the inhibition of ADP and AA-caused platelet aggregation, being 10.0- and 8.4-fold more efficient than (S)-NBP, respectively, also showing protection from acute thrombosis and inhibition of the I/R-related brain damage in animals.(222)
    Very recently, the same group designed and synthesized new NBP-ferulic acid-glucose hybrids in the search for new NBP derivatives with improved solubility in water and anti-ischemic activity.(223) These compounds inhibited ADP- or AA-mediated platelet aggregation, and among them, 2-methoxy-4-((E)-3-oxo-4-(((2R,3S,4R,5R)-3,4,5,6-tetrahydroxytetrahydro-2H-pyran-2-yl)methoxy)but-1-en-1-yl)phenyl 2-(1-((dimethylglycyl)oxy)pentyl)benzoate (NBP15) (Figure 25) was 30-fold more soluble in water and 10-fold more potent in inhibition of platelet aggregation than (RS)-NBP, decreased ROS generation, and protected primary neuronal cells from OGD/R-caused injury more efficiently than (RS)-NBP.(223)

    3.3.8. Edaravone/HPBA or NBP Hybrids

    Edaravone (Eda, Radicut) (Figure 1)(225) is a drug used in Japan to treat CI(226) and approved in Japan and South Korea in 2015 and by the US-FDA in 2017 and Chinese-NMPA in 2019 for the treatment of ALS.(227)Eda is a potent antioxidant, able to protect against OS and neuronal apoptosis.(228) Consequently, as expected, the design of Eda/HPBA or NBP hybrids has been a therapeutic option attracting interest from several laboratories in the last 5 years and affording new polyvalent small molecules for the therapy of CI and AD.
    3.3.8.1. Eda/HPBA Hybrids
    Zhang’s group reported(229) the synthesis and evaluation of 14 racemic Eda/PHPB hybrids of type IV (Figure 26) as potential anti-ischemic stroke agents. Hybrids IVa,b were synthesized by R1 (hydrogen, electron donating Me, OMe or electron withdrawing Cl, F, NO2) substitution at position C3′ or C4′ on the phenyl ring and/or R2 (methyl or trifluoromethyl) substitution at position C3′′ on the pyrazole ring. In vitro biological studies showed that hybrids 1-(3-chlorophenyl)-3-methyl-1H-pyrazol-5-yl 2-(1-acetoxypentyl)benzoate (NBP16) (Figure 26) and 1-(4-fluorophenyl)-3-methyl-1H-pyrazol-5-yl 2-(1-acetoxypentyl)benzoate (NBP17) (Figure 26) exhibited more potent antiplatelet aggregation than Ticlid, Asp, and (RS)-NBP. NBP17 reduced H2O2-mediated neuronal cell death more significantly than (RS)-NBP, Eda, or (RS)-NBP + Eda, being able to trap •OH or O2–•. The same group(230) also found that hybrid NBP17 reduced rat CI injury in vivo after oral administration (70 or 140 mg/kg) as shown by the reduction of the infarct volume and neurological impairment in MCAO rats, its neuroprotection being more pronounced than the protection afforded by NBP, Eda, or NBP + Eda. Furthermore, NBP17 significantly upregulated the protein amounts of the cytoprotective Bcl-2, HO-1, Nrf2, Trx, P-NF-κB p65, and IκB-α and decreased the expressions of Bax, caspases-3 and -9, Txnip, NF-κB p65, and P-IκB-α.
    3.3.8.2. Eda/NBP Hybrids
    Qiang and co-workers(231) designed racemic multitarget directed ligands(181) for AD therapy based on Eda/NBP hybrids V, which were synthesized as shown in Scheme 5.
    Reduction of isobenzofuran-1,3-dione (27) with sodium borohydride gave isobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (28) which, after radical bromination, afforded intermediate 3-bromoisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (29), whose hydrolysis produced 3-hydroxyisobenzofuran-1(3H)-one (30). Compound 30, after Grignard addition, gave phathalimides 31a–d, bearing n-alkyl chains of different lengths (n = 4, 5, 6, and 7) at C3, whose nitration afforded the expected C-6 nitro compounds 32a–d that upon reduction provided anilines 33a–d, whose treatment with sodium nitrite in acidic medium afforded the corresponding diazonium salts that led to the key hydrazines 34a–d after reduction. Finally, the reaction of 34a–d with ethyl trifluoroacetoacetate and NaOAc, at reflux, afforded the trifluoromethyl pyrazoles (not shown), while the reaction with ethyl acetoacetate and NaOAc, in EtOH, at reflux, gave the expected Eda/NBP hybrids Va–d.(231)
    Among Eda/NBP hybrids V, 2-(1-heptyl-3-oxo-1,3-dihydroisobenzofuran-5-yl)-5-methyl-2,4-dihydro-3H-pyrazol-3-one (NBP18) (Figure 27) was a potent (71% inhibition) self-induced Aβ1–42 aggregation inhibitor and an almost equipotent MAO A and B dual depressor, keeping the antioxidant activity of Eda.
    Hu et al.(232) described a new series of racemic Eda/NBP hybrids VI that were evaluated for their in vitro antiplatelet and antioxidant activities. The results indicated that (±)-1-(1-n-butyl-1,3-dihydro-3-oxoisobenzofuran-5-yl)-3-methyl-1H-pyrazol-5(4H)-one (NBP19) (Figure 27) showed similar potency of antiplatelet aggregation as (RS)-NBP and stronger hydroxyl radical scavenging activity (IC50 = 2.87 mM) than Eda (IC50 = 3.57 mM).

    4. Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    NBPs, including NBP as well as its derivatives and analogues, either in racemic or enantiomerically pure forms, have shown potent and diverse biological and pharmacological properties covering a large array of pathological targets from stroke to Alzheimer’s or Parkinson’s disease.(233,234)
    (S)-NBP increases brain microcirculation, reduces apoptosis,(235) inflammation, and mitochondrial dysfunction in suitable CI animal models,(162) protects against VaD via activation of the Akt kinase pathway,(236) protects against Aβ1–42, inhibits the induction of caspase-3 and NF-κB expression,(237) and significantly increases αAPPs release, reducing Aβ generation.(238) Preliminary biological investigations showed that (S)-NBP improves the cerebral blood flow and protects against ischemic injury.(239) It has also been reported that the effect of (S)-NBP on intracellular cyclic guanosine monophosphate and extracellular NO levels was antagonized by (R)-NBP.(240) Thus, (S)-NBP seems more promising than (R)-NBP in VaD and Aβ animal models.(89)
    However, in comparison with relatively less available (S)-NBP,(241)(RS)-NBP possesses several advantages such as easy access, relatively cheap price,(242) and diverse and rich biological properties. Therefore, (RS)-NBP is very well placed for drug repurposing/repositioning, as a current approach for clinically approved drugs to accelerate the drug discovery process for new therapeutic applications.(243) We will not be surprised to see that other human conditions with urgent, unmet treatment such as AD or ALS might profit in the next several years from (RS)-NBP potential clinical applications.
    Regarding the NBP derivatives/analogues, we must highlight PHPB, BZP, and ZJM-289. PHPB is able to reverse the cognitive impairment caused by chronic cerebral hypoperfusion, showing that the drug highly ameliorates the spatial learning and memory, decreases OD activity, and reduces lipid peroxide and astrocyte activation in the cortex of the hypoperfused rats,(206) acting as a pro-drug, whose conversion to (RS)-NBP is pH- and Ca2+-dependent.(207)PHPB is currently undergoing advanced clinical trials in China.(206,207)
    BZP is more active and secure than Br-NBP, owing in part to its ability to inhibit the mitochondrial apoptotic pathways and improve the neuroplasticity.(210)BZP is effective in the treatment and prevention of global CI,(211) able not only to reduce the infarct size and improve cardiac contractile function but also to protect the heart from chronic myocardium I/R related cardiac damage.(212) These results suggest that BZP may be a promising compound for treatment of pressure overload-induced cardiac remodeling and heart failure.(213)BZP has entered phase II clinical study in China.
    ZJM-289 exhibits stronger antithrombotic activity than (RS)-NBP and Asp in rats and protects against collagen and adrenaline-induced thrombosis in mice, confirming its potent antiplatelet aggregation and antithrombotic activity. It was demonstrated that both enantiomers are as potent as racemic ZJM-289 in inhibiting platelet aggregation, thrombosis, and neuroprotection, but (S)-ZJM-289 showed slightly better effects than (R)-ZJM-289 and (RS)-ZJM-289,(33) particularly at low doses, by enhancing mitochondrial function, reducing thus mitochondria-dependent cell death, and favoring survival signals.(217)
    To conclude, NBPs have already displayed a great potential therapeutic interest for many human conditions, especially for cerebral ischemia. We believe that with the intensive research of NBPs in the future, novel and better agents/drugs will be developed and benefit mankind.

    Author Information

        2
        The Structural Diversity of Phthalides from the Apiaceae
        Beck, John J.; Chou, Shen-Chieh
        Journal of Natural Products (2007), 70 (5), 891-900CODEN: JNPRDF; ISSN:0163-3864. (American Chemical Society-American Society of Pharmacognosy)
        A review. Phthalides, and their corresponding dihydro and tetrahydro analogs, are components of several genera of the plant family Apiaceae. These taxa have been reported as exhibiting a wide range of bioactivities against exptl. models of several illnesses and physiol. conditions, including microbial and viral infections, stroke, tuberculosis, and vasoconstriction. Many of these genera are purported to possess medicinal values, and of these several are considered to be traditional herbal medicines. This review provides an overview of the methods of investigation, the structural diversity, and the bioactivity of phthalides, dihydrophthalides, tetrahydrophthalides, and dimers from plants in the Apiaceae.
