        6
        Constituents of Umbelliferae. VIII. Distribution of alkyl-phthalides in Umbelliferae
        Mitsuhashi, Hiroshi; Muramatsu, Toshio; Nagai, Ukon; Nakano, Toshio; Ueno, Koji
        Chemical & Pharmaceutical Bulletin (1963), 11 (10), 1317-19CODEN: CPBTAL; ISSN:0009-2363.
        cf. CA 59, 11281a. The dried roots of Ligusticum acutilobum, a hybrid of L. acutilobum and Angelica anomala, Cnidium officinale, Apium graveolens, and Levisticum officinale were sepd., extd. with hexane, the ext. was dissolved in ether, washed with Na2CO3, NaOH, and H2O, dried over Na2SO4, the solvent evapd., the neutral oily residue distd., and the distillate chromatographed over silicic acid. The wt. of crude drug used, wt. neutral oil obtained, distn. temp., and yields of products of chromatography were: 3.5 kg. L. acutilobum, 23.5 g. oil, b4 80-120°, 122 mg. butylidenephthalide (I) (phthalazone, m. 153-4° ), 155 mg. ligustilide (II), 30.4 mg. sedanonic acid lactone (III) (phthalazone, m. 131-2°), and 170 mg. butylphthalide (IV); 13 kg. the hybrid, 40.5 g. oil, b1.6 115-34°, 403 mg. I and 801 mg. II; 11.1 kg. C. officinale, 400 g. oil, b2.5 147-50°, 1 g. I, 40 g. II, 3 g. cnidilide (V), and 1.6 g. neocnidilide (VI); 5.3 kg. A. graveolens, 44 g. oil, b4 100-117°, 156 mg. IV and 90 mg. VI; and 3.3 kg. L. officinale, 27.3 g. oil, b1 130-5°, 6.3 g. II and 255 mg. I. No alkylphthalides were obtained from the roots of A. anomala. Ultraviolet and infrared absorption data were reported for I-VI, and used in identifying them.

        7
        Constituents of Umbelliferae plants. IX. Structure of cnidilide and neocnidilide
        Mitsuhashi, H.; Muramatsu, T.
        Tetrahedron (1964), 20 (8), 1971-82CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020.
        cf. CA 60, 11044d. Dried powd. Cnidium officinale root (11.1 kg.) percolated with 30 l. C6H14 at 20°, the ext. (620 g.) in 2 l. Et2O treated with 10% aq. NaHCO3, 10% aq. Na2CO3, and 10% NaOH and washed with H2O, the dried Et2O ext. evapd., the neutral oil (400 g.) distd. in vacuo, the product (91 g.) chromatographed over 1.25 kg. silicic acid and eluted with CHCl3 and the eluates evapd. gave 46.5 g. ligustilide (I) and 28 g. lactone mixt. The mixt. was rechromatographed and sepd. to yield 3.0 g. cnidilide (II), 1.6 g. neocnidilide (III), and 1.2 g. substance δ, all practically devoid of the anticholinergic activity shown by I. II (1 g.) in 20 ml. alc. hydrogenated by shaking 5 min. with 5% Pd-C at 22°/l. atm. and the filtered soln. evapd. gave 1 g. β-dihydrosedanolide (IV), m. 49.0-9.8°, [α]25D -15.1° (c 6.2, CHCl3). IV (150 mg.) refluxed 6 hrs. in 6 ml. 5% alc. KOH, the alk. soln. acidified with 10% HCl at -15°, the cryst. ppt. taken up in Et2O and petr. ether at -15°, and the product recrystd. from the same solvent yielded 20 mg. β-dihydrosedanolic acid, m. 87-9°, [α]25D -27.59° (c 0.29, CHCl3). II (330 mg.) refluxed 5 hrs. with 25 ml. 5% KOH-MeOH, the MeOH replaced gradually in vacuo with H2O, the mixt. extd. with Et2O to recover 87.1 g. butyl phthalide, the alk. soln. acidified at 0° with 10% HCl and extd. with Et2O, and the fraction (211.4 mg.) hydrolyzed gave 87.5 mg. isocnidilide, b2 145°, [α]29D -80.0° (c 1.52 CHCl3), and 120.9 mg. acid fraction (V), m. 29-32°. V (20 mg.) refluxed (N atm.) in 5 ml. xylene 5 hrs. and the solvent evapd. gave a neutral oil contg. 10 mg. isocnidilide. V (96.4 mg.) oxidized at 20° with CrO3-C5H5N in C5H5N, the resulting oily substance (69.8 mg.) heated 3 hrs. at 100° in a sealed tube with an equal amt. of EtOH and N2H4.H2O, the mixt. cooled, and the product recrystd. from alc. gave 49.0 mg. sedanonic acid phthalazone (VI), m. 135-6°. II in CCl4 ozonized 1 hr. at -10° with 3.5% ozonized O, the mixt. evapd. at 20°, the product taken up in 30 ml. N NaOH and 30 ml. 5% H2O2, kept 1 hr. at 20°, and heated 3 hrs. at 60-80° with 10 ml. 5% H2O2, and the acidified soln. steam distd. gave 200 mg. volatile fraction and 1.1 g. Et2O-sol. residue. The volatile fraction in 20 ml. Et2O extd. with 10% aq. NaHCO3 and acidified gave Et2O-sol. butyl phthalide and NaHCO3-sol. valeric acid. The residual portion chromatographed on 300 mg. silicic acid and eluted with 19:1 CHCl3-BuOH gave 800 mg. oil, 50 mg. glutaric acid, and 50 mg. succinic acid. The oily fraction was distd. to give unidentified material (VII), b2 180-200°. II (3.0 g.) in 30 ml. dry Et2O treated with 3 g. OsO4 in 15 ml. dry Et2O 24 hrs. at 25°, the Et2O evapd., the Et2O-washed residue refluxed 2 hrs. with 8 ml. 40% NaHSO4 and 20 ml. 20% Na2SO3 in 30 ml. MeOH, the cooled mixt. filtered, the residue extd. with the same mixt. of NaHSO4 and Na2SO3 in MeOH, the combined alc. solns. evapd. in vacuo, the residue extd. with Et2O and evapd., and the oily product (2.85 g.) chromatographed on silicic acid and eluted with 99:1 CHCl3-MeOH gave 83 mg. glycol (VIII), m. 186-7° [(Me2CH)2O], [α]26D 6.76° (c 0.73, CHCl3), consuming 1.12 moles HIO4 in 19 hrs. at 22°, and 2.74 g. glycol (IX), m. 64-5°, [α]26D -23.1° (c 0.91, CHCl3), consuming 0.92 mole HIO4. IX (128 mg.) in 2 ml. C5H5N-Ac2O kept 12 hrs. at 25°, poured into H2O, and extd. with Et2O and the washed (0.5N HCl, 5% NaHCO3, H2O) and dried ext. evapd. gave 165 mg. diacetyl compd., m. 112-13°. VIII (58 mg.) similarly treated gave the corresponding diacetate (CHCl3). IX (285 mg.) in 10 ml. dioxane kept 24 hrs. at 25° in 10 ml. aq. HIO4 (0.5 mole) and dild. with 10 ml. H2O, the dioxane evapd. below 60°, the aq. layer extd. with Et2O, the product sepd. using 10% Na2CO3, and the fractions isolated gave 268 mg. neutral fraction with infrared spectrum similar to that of VII, and 11 mg. acid fraction, identified as HCO2H by gas and paper chromatography. The difference between isocnidilide (X) and II was reasonably explained by migration of the double bond of the lactone ring during lactone ring cleavage and closure. Similar expts. with Δ5-tetrahydrobutylphthalide (XI) resulted in recovery of XI and a small amt. of butyl phthalide. BuMgBr (from 1.2 mg. and 10 g. BuBr) in Et2O treated with 4.52 g. CdCl2 and the EtO replaced with C6H6 and treated with 3.75 g. cis-Δ4tetrahydrophthalic anhydride, the mixt. refluxed 2 hrs., treated with 10% H2SO4, extd. with Et2O, and evapd. and the oily product (4.36 g.) freed from cis-Δ4-tetrahydrophthalic acid by washing with dry C6H6 gave 2.6 g. oxo acid; 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazone m. 203.5°. The acid (2.3 g.) in 5 ml. 10% aq. NaOH treated with 0.5 g. NaBH4 in 5 ml. H2O, the mixt. kept 24 hrs. at 37°, acidified with 10% HCl, and extd. with Et2O, the residue (2.12 g.) on evapn. taken up in PhMe and refluxed 5 hrs., the cooled soln. washed with 10% aq. Na2CO3, and the solvent evapd. gave 0.5 g. XI. XI (0.4 g.) treated with 0.7 g. OsO4 gave 0.32 g. crystals, C12H20O4, m. 114-15°. XI (10.94 mg.) and 1 ml. 5% alc. KOH heated 8 hrs. in a sealed tube at 100°, the cooled mixt. evapd., the residue extd. with Et2O, and the solvent evapd. gave 5.14 mg. residue. III (150 mg.) refluxed 6 hrs. in 20 ml. 55% alc. KOH and dild. with 20 ml. H2O, the concd. aq. alk. soln. acidified at -15°, and the pptd. crystals taken up in 10% NaHCO3, washed with Et2O, and acidified with 10% HCl gave sedanonic acid, m. 81-2°. III (60 mg.) hydrolyzed with 10 ml. 10% KOH-EtOH and dild. with 10 ml. H2O, the soln. concd. to give 10 ml. distillate, the resulting aq. soln. acidified with 10% HCl, the acid fraction taken up in 5 ml. C5H5N and oxidized 14 hrs. at 20° with CrO3-C5H5N complex, the oxo acid heated in a sealed tube with alc. N2H4.H2O, and the product isolated gave VI, m. 134.5-5.0°. The chem. and phys. data suggest that X and III are stereoisomers and that III has the assigned formula. It was concluded from a comparison of phys. data that sedanolide reported by Ciamician and Silber [Ber. 30, 1427(1897)] is a mixt. of III and butyl phthalide.

        8
        The constitution of sedanolide
        Barton, D. H. R.; de Vries, Juan X.
        Journal of the Chemical Society (1963), (), 1916-19.CODEN: JCSOA9; ISSN:0368-1769.
        Celery oil has been found to furnish 3-butylphthalide and sedanoic acid. Sedanolide could not be reisolated. However, redn. of sedanonic acid with NaBH4 afforded racemic sedanolide, thus confirming a revised formulation for this compd. (I).

        9
        Relative recovery and identification of carbonyl compounds from celery essential oil
        Wilson, Charles Welthy III
        Journal of Food Science (1970), 35 (6), 766-8CODEN: JFDSAZ; ISSN:0022-1147.
        The major carbonyl compds. in the essential oil recovered from celery stalks and leaves were detd. The oils were prepd. by batch distn. and continuous distn., and not all components were found in oil recovered by the 2 methods. The major carbonyl constituents found were cis- and trans-limonene oxide, dihydrocarvone, α-ionone, butyl phenyl ketone, cis-3-hexen-1-yl acetate, pinocarvyl acetate, dihydrocarvol acetate, cis- and trans-carvyl acetate, cis-p-mentha-1,7(8)-dien-2-yl acetate, AcOH, tiglic acid, angelic acid, 3-butylhexahydrophthalide, 3-butylphthalide, sedanolide, and an unidentified carbonyl compd. 3-Butylphthalide and sedanolide exhibited the characteristic odor and flavor of celery.

      10. 10
        Chen, X.-Q.; Qiu, K.; Liu, H.; He, Q.; Bai, J.-H.; Lu, W. Application and Prospects of Butylphthalide for the Treatment of Neurologic Diseases. Chin. Med. J. 2019, 132, 1467– 1477,  DOI: 10.1097/CM9.0000000000000289
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        10
        Application and prospects of butylphthalide for the treatment of neurologic diseases
        Chen Xi-Qian; Qiu Ke; Liu Hui; He Qiang; Bai Jia-Hui; Lu Wei
        Chinese medical journal (2019), 132 (12), 1467-1477 ISSN:.
        OBJECTIVE: The 3-N-butylphthalide (NBP) comprises one of the chemical constituents of celery oil. It has a series of pharmacologic mechanisms including reconstructing microcirculation, protecting mitochondrial function, inhibiting oxidative stress, inhibiting neuronal apoptosis, etc. Based on the complex multi-targets of pharmacologic mechanisms of NBP, the clinical application of NBP is increasing and more clinical researches and animal experiments are also focused on NBP. The aim of this review was to comprehensively and systematically summarize the application of NBP on neurologic diseases and briefly summarize its application to non-neurologic diseases. Moreover, recent progress in experimental models of NBP on animals was summarized. DATA SOURCES: Literature was collected from PubMed and Wangfang database until November 2018, using the search terms including "3-N-butylphthalide," "microcirculation," "mitochondria," "ischemic stroke," "Alzheimer disease," "vascular dementia," "Parkinson disease," "brain edema," "CO poisoning," "traumatic central nervous system injury," "autoimmune disease," "amyotrophic lateral sclerosis," "seizures," "diabetes," "diabetic cataract," and "atherosclerosis." STUDY SELECTION: Literature was mainly derived from English articles or articles that could be obtained with English abstracts and partly derived from Chinese articles. Article type was not limited. References were also identified from the bibliographies of identified articles and the authors' files. RESULTS: NBP has become an important adjunct for ischemic stroke. In vascular dementia, the clinical application of NBP to treat severe cognitive dysfunction syndrome caused by the hypoperfusion of brain tissue during cerebrovascular disease is also increasing. Evidence also suggests that NBP has a therapeutic effect for neurodegenerative diseases. Many animal experiments have found that it can also improve symptoms in other neurologic diseases such as epilepsy, cerebral edema, and decreased cognitive function caused by severe acute carbon monoxide poisoning. Moreover, NBP has therapeutic effects for diabetes, diabetes-induced cataracts, and non-neurologic diseases such as atherosclerosis. Mechanistically, NBP mainly improves microcirculation and protects mitochondria. Its broad pharmacologic effects also include inhibiting oxidative stress, nerve cell apoptosis, inflammatory responses, and anti-platelet and anti-thrombotic effects. CONCLUSIONS: The varied pharmacologic mechanisms of NBP involve many complex molecular mechanisms; however, there many unknown pharmacologic effects await further study.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BB3M3ntlCgsg%253D%253D&md5=da64bdcfe2dec533061e8b51ce03fdff
      11. 11
        Xiong, M. J.; Li, Z. H. Progress in Syntheses of 3-n-Butylphthalide and its Analogues. Curr. Org. Chem. 2007, 11, 833– 844,  DOI: 10.2174/138527207780831738
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11
        Progress in syntheses of 3-n-butylphthalide and its analogues
        Xiong, Mo Jun; Li, Zhong Hui
        Current Organic Chemistry (2007), 11 (9), 833-844CODEN: CORCFE; ISSN:1385-2728. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
        A review. 3-N-Butylphthalide and its analogs, which are the main components in the volatile oil of celery as well as a wide range of umbelliferae and composite plants, have potential applications as hypotensive drugs because of their strong pharmacol. activities, such as improving the microcirculatory system of man's brain, improving nervous function deficiency, antiasthma, anticonvulsion, inhibiting platelet aggregation, inhibiting prostaglandin (PG) F2a growth, enhancing blood flow vol., antitumorigenesis, hypotensive activity and so on, so the investigation on the syntheses and applications of them has attracted considerable attention. The significant synthetic methods of 3-n-butylphthalide and its analogs were summarized and discussed in this review and it is expected that it may be valuable for their further development and applications.

        A review. Mols. contg. 3-substituted isobenzofuranones and isoindolinones skeletons are found in important bioactive compds. and in a no. of natural products. As a consequence several synthetic strategies, both asym. and non-asym., were developed. Thus, this review focuses on the main synthetic approaches to obtain these classes of compds., analyzing the common features, the scope and the limitations, and at the same time giving particular emphasis to the role of active methylene compds.

      14. 14
        Abdoulaye, I. A.; Guo, Y. J. A Review of Recent Advances in Neuroprotective Potential of 3-n-Butylphthalide and its Derivatives. BioMed Res. Int. 2016, 2016, 5012341,  DOI: 10.1155/2016/5012341
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14
        A Review of Recent Advances in Neuroprotective Potential of 3-N-Butylphthalide and Its Derivatives
        Abdoulaye Idriss Ali; Guo Yi Jing
        BioMed research international (2016), 2016 (), 5012341 ISSN:.
        The research of alternative treatment for ischemic stroke and degenerative diseases has always been a priority in neurology. 3-N-Butylphthalide (NBP), a family of compounds initially isolated from the seeds of Apium graveolens Linn., has shown significant neuroprotective effects. Previous extensive studies have demonstrated that NBP promotes a better poststroke outcome and exerts a multitargeted action on several mechanisms, from oxidative stress to mitochondrial dysfunction to apoptosis to inflammation. Additionally, recent findings on several neurological disorders have shown that NBP's beneficial effects extend beyond the management of stroke. However, despite the increasing number of studies toward a better understanding and the rapid advances made in therapeutic options, to date, dl-3-N-butylphthalide, a synthetic variation of l-3-N-butylphthalide, remains the only clinically approved anti-ischemic agent in China, stressing the difficulties for a viable and effective transition from experimental to clinical practice. Events indicate that NBP, due to its multitargeted effect and the adaptability of its basic structure, can be an important game changer and a precursor to a whole new therapeutic approach to several neurological conditions. The present review discusses recent advances pertaining to the neuroprotective mechanisms of NBP-derived compounds and the possibility of their clinical implementation in the management of various neurological conditions.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC1c7isVSitA%253D%253D&md5=1c95c006d6f60a7363086f9901cc9e2e
      15. 15
        Wang, S.; Ma, F.; Huang, L.; Zhang, Y.; Peng, Y.; Xing, C.; Feng, Y.; Wang, X.; Peng, Y. Dl-3-n-Butylphthalide (NBP): A Promising Therapeutic Agent for Ischemic Stroke. CNS Neurol. Disord.: Drug Targets 2018, 17, 338– 347,  DOI: 10.2174/1871527317666180612125843
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        15
        Dl-3-n-Butylphthalide (NBP): A Promising Therapeutic Agent for Ischemic Stroke
        Wang, Shan; Ma, Fei; Huang, Longjian; Zhang, Yong; Peng, Yuchen; Xing, Changhong; Feng, Yipu; Wang, Xiaoliang; Peng, Ying
        CNS & Neurological Disorders: Drug Targets (2018), 17 (5), 338-347CODEN: CNDDA3; ISSN:1871-5273. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
        Background and Objective: Stroke is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in both developed and developing countries all over the world. The only drug for ischemic stroke approved by FDA is recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA). However, only 2-5% stroke patients receive rtPAs treatment due to its strict therapeutic time window. As ischemic stroke is a complex disease involving multiple mechanisms, medications with multi-targets may be more powerful compared with single-target drugs. Dl-3-n-Butylphthalide (NBP) is a synthetic compd. based on l-3-n- Butylphthalide that is isolated from seeds of Apium graveolens. The racemic 3-n-butylphthalide (dl- NBP) was approved by Food and Drug Administration of China for the treatment of ischemic stroke in 2002. A no. of clin. studies indicated that NBP not only improved the symptoms of ischemic stroke, but also contributed to the long-term recovery. The potential mechanisms of NBP for ischemic stroke treatment may target different pathophysiol. processes, including anti-oxidant, antiinflammation, anti-apoptosis, anti-thrombosis, and protection of mitochondria et al. Conclusion: In this review, we have summarized the research progress of NBP for the treatment of ischemic stroke during the past two decades.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhsFeiurfM&md5=db34db2060316af6f03e3d86cedb904b
      16. 16
        Xu, Z.-Q.; Zhou, Y.; Shao, B.-Z.; Zhang, J.-J.; Liu, C. A Systematic Review of Neuroprotective Efficacy and Safety of DL3-n-butylphthalide in Ischemic Stroke. Am. J. Chin. Med. 2019, 47, 507– 525,  DOI: 10.1142/S0192415X19500265
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16
        A Systematic Review of Neuroprotective Efficacy and Safety of DL-3-N-Butylphthalide in Ischemic Stroke
        Xu, Zhe-Qi; Zhou, Yi; Shao, Bo-Zong; Zhang, Jing-Jing; Liu, Chong
        American Journal of Chinese Medicine (2019), 47 (3), 507-525CODEN: AJCMBA; ISSN:0192-415X. (World Scientific Publishing Co. Pte. Ltd.)
        A review. Major databases were searched to identify randomized controlled trials that assessed efficacy and safety of NBP on ischemic stroke, reporting outcomes among patients treated with NBP alone or combined with std. anti-ischemic stroke drugs vs. std. anti-ischemic stroke drugs. Extd. and synthesized of standardized mean differences by random effects models, while dichotomous data were validated, extd. and synthesized of relative risk by random effects models. Twelve randomized controlled trials involving 1160 patients were identified. NBP monotherapy is not superior to std. anti-ischemic stroke drugs based on Barthel Index (SMD, 0.25; 95% CI -0.14 to 0.63; P=0.21) and National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (SMD, 0.73; 95% CI -0.14 to 1.59; P=0.10). Combination of NBP and std. anti-ischemic stroke drugs appears to be superior to std. drugs alone, again based on both Barthel index (SMD, 1.65; 95% CI 1.25 to 2.04; P<0.01) and National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (SMD, 1.40; 95% CI 0.72 to 2.09; P<0.01). Use of NBP may cause adverse event on the function of liver (RR, 3.55; 95% CI 1.19 to 10.56; P<0.05). Combination use of NBP and std. anti-ischemic stroke drugs is more effective than std. drugs. More attention should be payed to adverse effects on liver function. Our findings provided established evidence of NBP as neuroprotective drug, which may improve current guideline for treatment of ischemic stroke.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhtVWqtrjL&md5=2fb8629ed6dd06d7734a5ba6434630f2
      17. 17
        Li, L.; Si, Y.-K. Study on the Absolute Configurations of 3-Alkylphthalides using TDDFT Calculations of Chiroptical Properties. Chirality 2012, 24, 987– 993,  DOI: 10.1002/chir.22086
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17
        Study on the Absolute Configurations of 3-Alkylphthalides using TDDFT Calculations of Chiroptical Properties
        Li, Li; Si, Yi-Kang
        Chirality (2012), 24 (12), 987-993CODEN: CHRLEP; ISSN:0899-0042. (Wiley-Liss, Inc.)
        Abs. configurations (ACs) of 3-alkylphthalides including natural products (-)-3-n-butylphthalide ((-)-1) and fuscinarin have been studied using chiroptical properties and quantum chem. calcn. Electronic CD and ORD spectra of (S)-1 predicted adopting time-dependent d. functional theory and hybrid functionals coincide very well with the exptl. and literature data of (-)-1, leading unambiguously to AC assignment as S for levorotatory isomer. The relationship between structures and chiroptical properties of 3-alkylphthalides were also studied using theor. calcn. It is found that when the alkyl group is adjacent to the single chiral center in the mol., both the length of the alkyl side chain and the polarity of solvent may exert significant effect on electronic CD spectra. On the basis of these observations, it is recommended that the long-chain alkyl group may be replaced by at least Pr instead of Me group in such compds. The present work shows that combination of chiroptical properties and ab initio calcns. can provide a feasible and reliable way to the AC establishment of novel 3-alkylphthalide derivs. with a high degree of confidence. Chirality, 2012. © 2012 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtVehs7vN&md5=2efe3e64a6331c79c7b7e664867b8b40
      18. 18
        Luo, L.; Song, Q.; Li, Y.; Cao, Z.; Qiang, X.; Tan, Z.; Deng, Y. Design, Synthesis and Evaluation of Phthalide Alkyl Tertiary Amine Derivatives as Promising Acetylcholinesterase Inhibitors with High Potency and Selectivity Against Alzheimer’s Disease. Bioorg. Med. Chem. 2020, 28, 115400,  DOI: 10.1016/j.bmc.2020.115400
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        18
        Design, synthesis and evaluation of phthalide alkyl tertiary amine derivatives as promising acetylcholinesterase inhibitors with high potency and selectivity against Alzheimer's disease
        Luo, Li; Song, Qing; Li, Yan; Cao, Zhongcheng; Qiang, Xiaoming; Tan, Zhenghuai; Deng, Yong
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry (2020), 28 (8), 115400CODEN: BMECEP; ISSN:0968-0896. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A series of phthalide alkyl tertiary amine derivs. I, II and III [R1 = Me, Et; R = Et, MeO, Bn, 2-MeOBn, 2-Me2NBn] were designed, synthesized and evaluated as potential multi-target agents against Alzheimer's disease (AD). The results indicated that almost all the compds. I, II and III displayed significant AChE inhibitory and selective activities. Besides, most of the derivs. I, II and III exhibited increased self-induced Aβ1-42 aggregation inhibitory activity compared to the lead compd. DL-NBP, and some compds. also exerted good antioxidant activity. Specifically, compd. I [R1 = R2 = Et] showed the highest inhibitory potency toward AChE (IC50 = 2.66 nM), which was significantly better than Donepezil (IC50 = 26.4 nM). Moreover, mol. docking studies revealed that compd. I [R1 = R2 = Et] was bind to both the catalytic active site and peripheral anionic site of AChE. Furthermore, compd. I [R1 = R2 = Et] displayed excellent BBB permeability in-vitro. Importantly, the step-down passive avoidance test indicated that I [R1 = R2 = Et] significantly reversed scopolamine-induced memory deficit in mice. Collectively, these results suggested that I [R1 = R2 = Et] was a potent and selective AChE inhibitor for further anti-AD drug development.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXktl2nu7Y%253D&md5=7f1615a55231729ee20acd8d6a3dcce5
      19. 19
        Lian, Y.; Bergman, R. G.; Ellman, J. A. Rhodium(III)-Catalyzed Synthesis of Phthalides by Cascade Addition and Cyclization of Benzimidates with Aldehydes. Chem. Sci. 2012, 3, 3088– 3092,  DOI: 10.1039/c2sc20835k
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        19
        Rhodium(III)-catalyzed synthesis of phthalides by cascade addition and cyclization of benzimidates with aldehydes
        Lian, Yajing; Bergman, Robert G.; Ellman, Jonathan A.
        Chemical Science (2012), 3 (10), 3088-3092CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The authors herein report the Rh(III)-catalyzed carbon-hydrogen bond (C-H bond) activation and addn. of benzimidate derivs. to aldehydes to afford biol. important phthalides in a single step. The imidate is a novel and unexplored directing group that not only enables C-H bond activation and addn. to aldehydes, but also serves to capture the reversibly formed alc. intermediate. The reaction shows broad scope with a high level of functional group compatibility and is applicable to both arom. and aliph. aldehydes. The title compds. thus formed included 3-(4-chlorophenyl)-1(3H)-isobenzofuranone (I) and related substances, such as 1,3-dihydro-3-oxo-1-isobenzofurancarboxylic acid Et ester. The synthesis of the target compds. was achieved using [C(Z)]-N-methoxybenzenecarboximidic acid Me ester (II) and similar imidates as key intermediates.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xht1ymtrjP&md5=ea8dc13e5bcec447b3def0cb10848fad
      20. 20
        Kuethe, J. T.; Maloney, K. M. A Concise Synthesis of 3,4-Fused Spiro[isobenzofuran-3-ones], Spiro[furo[3,4-b]pyridin-5(7H)-ones], 3-Aryl-, and Alkylphthalides. Tetrahedron 2013, 69, 5248– 5258,  DOI: 10.1016/j.tet.2013.02.051
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        20
        A concise synthesis of 3,4-fused spiro[isobenzofuran-3-ones], spiro[furo[3,4-b]pyridin-5(7H)-ones], 3-aryl-, and alkylphthalides
        Kuethe, Jeffrey T.; Maloney, Kevin M.
        Tetrahedron (2013), 69 (25), 5248-5258CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A synthetically useful protocol was developed for the prepn. of highly functionalized 3,4-fused spiro[isobenzofuran-3-ones], spiro[furo[3,4-b]pyridin-5(7H)-ones], 3-aryl-, and alkylphthalides. Reaction of 2-iodobenzoate esters and 2-iodopyridine carboxylate esters with i-PrMgCl·LiCl in the presence of cyclic ketones under std. Barbier reaction conditions affords 3,4-fused spiro[isobenzofuran-3-ones] and spiro[furo[3,4-b]pyridin-5(7H)-ones] in good to excellent yields. Step-wise addn. of i-PrMgCl·LiCl to 2-iodobenzoate esters followed by trapping with various aldehydes yields 3-aryl and 3-alkylphthalides; whereas, under similar conditions access to 3-aryl and 3-alylazaphthalides is also possible. Extension of this methodol. toward the prepn. of 3-n-butylphthalide and chrycolide, a natural product isolated from the leaves and stems of Chrysanthemum coronarium, is also described.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXmvFygsLo%253D&md5=fd94326a39be39a0746ac62bbc4d26c9

        Copper(I) bromide-catalyzed carbonylative coupling of aryl halides with phenols, alcohols, and amines using sodium cyanide as C1 source. A synthesis of carboxylic acid derivatives
        Prasad, Pragati K.; Sudalai, Arumugam
        Advanced Synthesis & Catalysis (2014), 356 (10), 2231-2238CODEN: ASCAF7; ISSN:1615-4150. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A new carbon monoxide-free synthesis of carboxylate derivs. via carbonylative coupling of aryl bromides with phenols, alcs., amines and acids in the presence of copper(I) bromide as catalyst and sodium cyanide in a stoichiometric amt. was developed. Its intramol. version provides for the prepn. of lactones (e.g., isochroman-1-ones and isobenzofuranones), imides, anhydrides and lactams in excellent yields (73-96%).

        Transition-metal-free synthesis of (Z)-3-ylidenephthalides from 2-acyl-benzoic acids
        He, Xinhua; Xue, Fengtian
        Tetrahedron Letters (2014), 55 (11), 1956-1958CODEN: TELEAY; ISSN:0040-4039. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        We report a highly efficient method for the synthesis of (Z)-3-ylidenephthalides via intramol. cyclization of readily available 2-acyl-benzoic acids mediated by TSTU at room temp. Using this method, diversely substituted (Z)-3-ylidenephthalides have been generated in good to excellent yields. The application of the method is highlighted by gram-scale prepn. of the antiplatelet drug n-butylphthalide.

        Dey, S.; Gadakh, S. K.; Sudalai, A. Titanium superoxide – a Stable Recyclable Heterogeneous Catalyst for Oxidative Esterification of Aldehydes with Alkylarenes or Alcohols Using TBHP as an Oxidant. Org. Biomol. Chem. 2015, 13, 10631– 10640,  DOI: 10.1039/C5OB01586C
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        23
        Titanium superoxide - a stable recyclable heterogeneous catalyst for oxidative esterification of aldehydes with alkylarenes or alcohols using TBHP as an oxidant
        Dey, Soumen; Gadakh, Sunita K.; Sudalai, A.
        Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2015), 13 (43), 10631-10640CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A variety of esters, e.g., C6H5CO2CH2C6H5 were synthesized in excellent yields by the oxidative esterification of corresponding aldehydes RCHO (R = CH2=CH, 4-O2NC6H4, 3-BrC6H4, pyridin-3-yl, etc.) with alkylarenes R1H (R1 = C6H5CH2, 3-H3CC6H4CH2, 1-phenylethyl, etc.) or alcs. e.g., C6H5CH2OH using titanium superoxide as a stable recyclable catalyst, under truly heterogeneous conditions. Mechanistic studies have established that this "one pot" direct oxidative esterification process proceeds through a radical pathway, proven by a FTIR spectral study of a titanium superoxide-aldehyde complex as well as spin trapping expts. with TEMPO. The intramol. version of this protocol has been successfully demonstrated in the concise synthesis of 3-butylphthalide, an anti-convulsant drug.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhsVGjur7K&md5=60532ff9c14b6e4b1525f71e6248e384

        Suchand, B.; Satyanarayana, G. Palladium-Catalyzed Environmentally Benign Acylation. J. Org. Chem. 2016, 81, 6409– 6423,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.joc.6b01064
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        24
        Palladium-Catalyzed Environmentally Benign Acylation
        Suchand, Basuli; Satyanarayana, Gedu
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (2016), 81 (15), 6409-6423CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
        Recent trends in research have gained an orientation toward developing efficient strategies using innocuous reagents. The earlier reported transition-metal-catalyzed carbonylations involved either toxic carbon monoxide (CO) gas as carbonylating agent or functional-group-assisted ortho sp2 C-H activation (i.e., ortho acylation) or carbonylation by activation of the carbonyl group (i.e., via the formation of enamines). Contradicting these methods, here we describe an environmentally benign process, [Pd]-catalyzed direct carbonylation starting from simple and com. available iodo arenes and aldehydes, for the synthesis of a wide variety of ketones. Moreover, this method comprises direct coupling of iodoarenes with aldehydes without activation of the carbonyl and also without directing group assistance. Significantly, the strategy was successfully applied to the synthesis n-butylphthalide and pitofenone.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtFSrtLbL&md5=415ad0ea7813a2386dc279684b8a8136

        Aand, D.; Karekar, S.; Mahajan, B.; Pawar, A. B.; Singh, A. K. Controlled Photo-flow Oxidative Reaction (UV-FOR) Platform for Ultra-fast Phthalide and API Synthesis. Green Chem. 2018, 20, 4584– 4590,  DOI: 10.1039/C8GC02320D
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        26
        Controlled photo-flow oxidative reaction (UV-FOR) platform for ultra-fast phthalide and API synthesis
        Aand, Dnyaneshwar; Karekar, Sanjeev; Mahajan, Bhushan; Pawar, Amit B.; Singh, Ajay K.
        Green Chemistry (2018), 20 (20), 4584-4590CODEN: GRCHFJ; ISSN:1463-9262. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        An integrated photo-flow oxidative reaction (UV-FOR) platform approach is presented for the synthesis of phthalides. The current protocol is catalyst-free, and uses economical and abundant hydro-carbons and hydrocarbon derivs. such as benzoic acid, benzene, and xylene, as starting materials. The reaction is performed using oxygen as a green oxidant in a time- and labour-efficient manner. This integrated approach has been shown to be successful in making a UV-FOR platform suitable for the on-demand synthesis of phthalides and their further syntheses to 2-arylmethylbenzoic acids and arylogous Michael addn. products under relatively mild conditions. The current protocol was further extended to the gram scale synthesis of an ischemic stroke-relevant active pharmaceutical ingredient (API), 3-N-butylphthalide (NBP), in a continuous flow process.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhs12hsr%252FI&md5=fba04b34eb4bf90538bc287d717f6aac

        Suchand, B.; Sreenivasulu, C.; Satyanarayana, G. Palladium-Catalyzed Direct Oxidative Coupling of Iodoarenes with Primary Alcohols Leading to Ketones: Application to the Synthesis of Benzofuranones and Indenones. Eur. J. Org. Chem. 2019, 2019, 4832– 4843,  DOI: 10.1002/ejoc.201900769
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        27
        Palladium-Catalyzed Direct Oxidative Coupling of Iodoarenes with Primary Alcohols Leading to Ketones: Application to the Synthesis of Benzofuranones and Indenones
        Suchand, Basuli; Sreenivasulu, Chinnabattigalla; Satyanarayana, Gedu
        European Journal of Organic Chemistry (2019), 2019 (30), 4832-4843CODEN: EJOCFK; ISSN:1099-0690. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        In the present study, a palladium-catalyzed direct oxidative acylation through cross-dehydrogenative coupling has been investigated, utilizing readily available primary alcs. as acylating sources. Overall, this oxidative coupling proceeds via three distinct transformations such as oxidn., radical formation, and cross-coupling in one catalytic process. This protocol does not involve the assistance of a directing group or activation of the carbonyl group by any other means. Furthermore, this reaction made use of no toxic CO gas as carbonylating agent; instead, feedstock primary alcs. have been utilized as acylation source. Notably, the synthesis of benzofuranones and indenones is enabled. This strategy was also applied to the synthesis of n-butylphthalide, fenofibrate, pitofenone, and neo-lignan. Thus, e.g., Me 2-iodobenzoate + benzyl alc. → Me 2-benzoylbenzoate (64%) in presence of Pd(OAc)2, Ag2O and TBHP.

Ortho-bromo benzaldehyde and naphthalene were opted as starting materials. Compared to previous proposed methods, Reaction times were short, the procedure and work-up were simple. Using inexpensive, readily available starting materials and the yield of reaction were considered as the next highlighted points According to gained data from HPLC and NMR, the way in which Ortho-bromo benzaldehyde was used was noticeable in terms of efficiency and purity, being 89.74% and 72% resp. On the other hand, naphthalene used in this synthesis was not at all comparable to Ortho-bromo benzaldehyde regarding efficiency and purity, with 37.15% and 23% resp.

      30. 30
        Chang, H.-T.; Jeganmohan, M.; Cheng, C.-H. Highly Efficient Cyclization of o-Iodobenzoateswith AldehydesCatalyzed by Cobalt Bidentate Phosphine Complexes: A Novel Entry to Chiral Phthalides. Chem. - Eur. J. 2007, 13, 4356– 4363,  DOI: 10.1002/chem.200601880
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        30
        Highly efficient cyclization of ortho-iodobenzoates with aldehydes catalyzed by cobalt bidentate phosphine complexes: a novel entry to chiral phthalides
        Chang, Hong-Tai; Jeganmohan, Masilamani; Cheng, Chien-Hong
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2007), 13 (15), 4356-4363CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Me 2-iodobenzoates undergo cyclization reaction with various arom. aldehydes, such as benzaldehyde and benzofuran-2-carbaldehyde, in the presence of [CoI2(dppe)] (dppe = 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane) and Zn powder in dry THF at 75° for 24 h to give the corresponding phthalide derivs. in good to excellent yields. Under similar reaction conditions, less reactive aliph. aldehydes, such as heptanal, give phthalides in fair to good yields. The catalytic reaction can be further extended to cinnamyl aldehyde with Me 2-iodobenzoate to give (E)-3-styrlysobenzofuran-1(3H)-one in 65% yield. This synthetic method is compatible with a variety of functional groups on the aryl ring of the aldehydes. An asym. version of the catalytic reaction by employing cobalt catalysts with bidentate chiral ligands, as exemplified by [CoI2{(S,S)-dipamp}] ((S,S)-dipamp = (1S,2S)-(+)-bis[(2-methoxyphenyl)phenylphosphino]ethane), is also developed, which gives the corresponding (S)-phthalides in 81-89% yields with 70-98% ee. A possible mechanism for the catalytic reaction is proposed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXmtF2ntb0%253D&md5=6049855a565b0bd33971ddf5f9bc4f9b

        Synthesis, resolution, and antiplatelet activity of 3-substituted 1(3H)-isobenzofuranone
        Yang, Hua; Hu, Gao-Yun; Chen, Jun; Wang, Yi; Wang, Zhong-Hua
        Bioorganic & Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2007), 17 (18), 5210-5213CODEN: BMCLE8; ISSN:0960-894X. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A series of 3-substituted-1(3H)-isobenzofuranones were synthesized from phthalic anhydride. The 3-alkyl-1(3H)-isobenzofuranones, e.g., I, was resolved. The antiplatelet activities of these compds. were evaluated using in vitro expt. of platelet aggregation. The levels of antiplatelet activity were displayed as following sequence: L-isomer > DL-isomer > D-isomer, resp. The 3-alkyl-1(3H)-isobenzofuranones is more active than the corresponding the 3-alkene-1(3H)-isobenzofuranones. All these compds. were less active than n-butylphthalide (NBP) and Aspirin (Asp).

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXpt1emtbc%253D&md5=7cbd865b7a278e43027420b33f8e5602
      33. 33
        Wang, X.; Zhao, Q.; Wang, X.; Li, T.; Lai, Y.; Peng, S.; Ji, H.; Xu, J.; Zhang, Y. Studies on the Enantiomers of ZJM-289: Synthesis and Biological Evaluation of Antiplatelet, Antithrombotic and Neuroprotective Activities. Org. Biomol. Chem. 2012, 10, 9030– 9040,  DOI: 10.1039/c2ob26511g
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        33
        Studies on the enantiomers of ZJM-289: synthesis and biological evaluation of antiplatelet, antithrombotic and neuroprotective activities
        Wang, Xiaoli; Zhao, Qian; Wang, Xuliang; Li, Tingting; Lai, Yisheng; Peng, Sixun; Ji, Hui; Xu, Jinyi; Zhang, Yihua
        Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry (2012), 10 (45), 9030-9040CODEN: OBCRAK; ISSN:1477-0520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        ZJM-289 is a potent racemic agent which inhibits both platelet aggregation and thrombosis superior to a known anti-ischemic stroke drug 3-n-butylphthalide (NBP). Herein, the enantiomers of ZJM-289, (S)-ZJM-289 and (R)-ZJM-289, were synthesized and evaluated for their biol. activities. It was obsd. that the two enantiomers appeared to be almost as effective as ZJM-289 in inhibiting platelet aggregation in vitro and thrombus formation in vivo. Moreover, like ZJM-289, its enantiomers could regulate the ratio of thromboxane B2 (TXB2) and 6-keto-prostaglandin F1α, and enhanced levels of nitric oxide (NO), cAMP and cGMP, suggesting that the anti-platelet and antithrombotic activities of the enantiomers and ZJM-289 are assocd. with both the arachidonic acid cascade and cGMP-NO signal pathway. Furthermore, it was found that oral administration of the enantiomers and ZJM-289 for three days significantly reduced the infarct size, brain water content and neurol. deficit in rats after cerebral ischemia reperfusion. Importantly, the two enantiomers equally improved blood flow in the ischemic stroke model and modulated endothelial function through releasing moderate levels of NO, which might, at least partially, contribute to their neuroprotection. Collectively, the present study demonstrates that the two enantiomers are as potent as ZJM-289 in inhibition of platelet aggregation and thrombosis and in neuroprotection, and (S)-ZJM-289 shows somewhat better effects than (R)-ZJM-289 and ZJM-289 in a few cases. These findings may provide new insights into the development of therapeutic agents like ZJM-289 for the intervention of thrombosis-related ischemic stroke.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhsF2qtLvP&md5=b5b5471827c01b1d064c12a4c4f95c6f
      34. 34
        He, L.; Li, C.; Gao, B. Novozyme 435-Catalyzed Asymmetric Acylation of (R,S)-3-n-Butylphthalide in Hexane. Prep. Biochem. Biotechnol. 2009, 39, 266– 276,  DOI: 10.1080/10826060902953004
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        34
        Novozyme 435-Catalyzed Asymmetric Acylation of (R, S)-3-n-Butylphthalide in Hexane
        He, Laping; Li, Cuiqin; Gao, Bing
        Preparative Biochemistry & Biotechnology (2009), 39 (3), 266-276CODEN: PBBIF4; ISSN:1082-6068. (Taylor & Francis, Inc.)
        The asym. acylation of (R, S)-3-n-butylphthalide could be efficiently catalyzed by Novozyme 435. The effect of various reaction parameters such as water activity, temp., molar ratio of acetic anhydride to (R, S)-3-n-butylphthalide, and reaction time on the asym. acylation were studied. The optimums of the reaction parameters were water activity 0.62, temp. 30°, molar ratio of acetic anhydride to (R, S)-3-n-butylphthalide 8:1, and reaction time 48 h, resp. Under the optimum conditions, enantiopure 3-n-butylphthalide with an optical purity of 95.7% enantiomeric excess and 49.1% yield could be obtained. Furthermore, the enantiomeric excess of product was over 98%.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXls1ersr8%253D&md5=65a59ba8855a99ffc09e19637b3654d0
      35. 35
        Li, C.; He, L.; Qiu, B.; Gao, B. An Efficient System for the Asymmetric Acylation of (R,S)-3-n-Butylphthalide Catalyzed by Novozyme 435. Prep. Biochem. Biotechnol. 2010, 40, 354– 365,  DOI: 10.1080/15226514.2010.525423
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        35
        An efficient system for the asymmetric acylation of (R,S)-3-n-butylphthalide catalyzed by Novozyme 435
        Li, Cuiqin; He, Laping; Qiu, Baoquan; Gao, Bing
        Preparative Biochemistry & Biotechnology (2010), 40 (4), 354-365CODEN: PBBIF4; ISSN:1082-6068. (Taylor & Francis, Inc.)
        Novozyme 435 could be a highly efficient catalyst in the asym. acylation of (R,S)-3-n-butylphthalide in tetrahydrofuran-hexane solvents. The effect of various reaction parameters such as agitation velocity, water content, mixed media, temp., concn. of Novozyme 435, molar ratio of acetic anhydride to (R,S)-3-n-butylphthalide, reaction time, enantiomeric excess of substrate (eeS), enantiomeric excess of product (eeP), and enantioselective ratio (E) were studied. THF markedly improved (R,S)-3-n-butylphthalide conversion, enantiomeric excess of remaining 3-n-butylphthalide, and enantiomeric ratio. The optimum media were 50% (vol./vol.) THF and 50% (vol./vol.) hexane. Other ideal reaction conditions were an agitation velocity of 150 rpm, 0.4% (vol./vol.) water content, temp. of 30°C, 8 mg/mL dosage of Novozyme 435, 8:1 (0.4 mmol:0.05 mmol) molar ratio of acetic anhydride to (R,S)-3-n-butylphthalide, and a reaction time of 48 h. Under the optimum conditions, 96.4% eeS and 49.3% conversion of (R,S)-3-n-butylphthalide were achieved. In addn., enantiomeric excess of the product was above 98.0%.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhsVOgurbM&md5=cc369303f22e7cdb9309a6328e8ad2e2
      36. 36
        He, L.; Sun, J.; Xu, Y.; Sun, Z.; Zheng, C. Novozyme 435-Catalyzed Efficient Acylation of 3-n-Butylphthalide in Organic Medium. Prep. Biochem. Biotechnol. 2008, 38, 376– 388,  DOI: 10.1080/10826060802325501
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        36
        Novozyme 435-Catalyzed Efficient Acylation of 3-n-Butylphthalide in Organic Medium
        He, Laping; Sun, Jiong; Xu, Yan; Sun, Zhihao; Zheng, Changge
        Preparative Biochemistry & Biotechnology (2008), 38 (4), 376-388CODEN: PBBIF4; ISSN:1082-6068. (Taylor & Francis, Inc.)
        Novozyme 435 could catalyze efficient acylation of 3-n-butylphthalide in org. medium. The conversion of 3-n-butylphthalide increased with the increase of hydrophobicity of solvent below that of hexane. The more available solvent was hexane. Salt hydride could control fixed water activity. The optimum water activity was 0.62. And the optimum of reaction time, velocity of agitation, dosage of Novozyme 435 and acetic anhydride to 3-n-butylphthalide molar ratio were 48 h, 150 rpm, 8 mg/mL and 8:1, resp. The conversion of 48.9% could be obtained at a water activity of 0.62 in hexane. Furthermore, Novozyme 435 had an enantioselective acylation of racemic 3-n-butylphthalide by original anal.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        He, L.; Sun, J.; Xu, Y.; Sun, Z. H. A Novel method to Resolve (R,S)-3-n-Butylphthalide Catalyzed by Novozyme 435 in Microaqueous Medium. Process Biochem. 2008, 43, 1215– 1219,  DOI: 10.1016/j.procbio.2008.07.001
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        37
        A novel method to resolve (R,S)-3-n-butylphthalide catalyzed by Novozyme 435 in microaqueous medium
        He, Laping; Sun, Jiong; Xu, Yan; Sun, Zhi Hao
        Process Biochemistry (Amsterdam, Netherlands) (2008), 43 (11), 1215-1219CODEN: PBCHE5; ISSN:1359-5113. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The enantioselective resoln. of (R,S)-3-n-butylphthalide can be achieved by Novozyme 435-catalyzed transesterification in microaq. medium. We studied the influence of org. solvent and initial water activity on this resoln. THF markedly improved the conversion of (R,S)-3-n-butyl-phthalide, the enantiomeric excess of remaining 3-n-butylphthalide, and the enantiomeric ratio. The optimum solvents were mixts. (1.9 mL) of 50% (vol/vol) THF and 50% (vol/vol) hexane. The optimal initial water activity was 0.62, and the optimal molar ratio of vinyl acetate to (R,S)-3-n-butylphthalide (0.4:0.05 mmol) was 8:1 in a 2.0-mL reaction system contg. the optimized solvents (1.9 mL). In addn., the optimal reaction time was 48 h. Under these conditions, enantiopure 3-n-butylphthalide with an optical purity of 97.2% enantiomeric excess and 49.5% yield could be obtained at 30°. Furthermore, the enantiomeric excess of product was over 98%.

        Phan, D. H. T.; Kim, B.; Dong, V. M. Phthalides by Rhodium-Catalyzed Ketone Hydroacylation. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 15608– 15609,  DOI: 10.1021/ja907711a
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        38
        Phthalides by Rhodium-Catalyzed Ketone Hydroacylation
        Phan, Diem H. T.; Kim, Byoungmoo; Dong, Vy M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (43), 15608-15609CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Phthalides are biol. relevant five-membered lactones found in herbs, fruits, and vegetables. Herein we communicate the first atom-economical approach to phthalides by using enantioselective ketone hydroacylation. In the presence of Rh[(Duanphos)]X (X = NO3, OTf, OMs), various 2-ketobenzaldehydes undergo intramol. hydroacylation to produce phthalide products in good yields and 92-98% ee's. Our study highlights the key role counterions play in controlling both reactivity and enantioselectivity. A concise asym. total synthesis of the celery ext. (S)-(-)-3-n-butylphthalide (I) is also presented.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXht1Cjs73J&md5=2ae54fd2c17cd31ffcc5b26bca679bfb

        Catalytic Enantioselective Synthesis of Chiral Phthalides by Efficient Reductive Cyclization of 2-Acylarylcarboxylates under Aqueous Transfer Hydrogenation Conditions
        Zhang, Bo; Xu, Ming-Hua; Lin, Guo-Qiang
        Organic Letters (2009), 11 (20), 4712-4715CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7060. (American Chemical Society)
        A new diamine ligand for asym. transfer hydrogenation (ATH) was discovered. The reductive cyclization of 2-acylarylcarboxylates e.g I, was found to proceed highly stereoselectively by the new Ru complex-catalyzed ATH and subsequent in situ lactonization under aq. conditions. It enables efficient access to a wide variety of 3-substituted phthalides e.g. II, in enantiomerically pure form.

        Zhang, H.; Zhang, S.; Liu, L.; Luo, G.; Duan, W.; Wang, W. Synthesis of Chiral 3-Substituted Phthalides by a Sequential Organocatalytic Enantioselective Aldol-Lactonization Reaction. Three-Step Synthesis of (S)-(−)-3-Butylphthalide. J. Org. Chem. 2010, 75, 368– 374,  DOI: 10.1021/jo902118x
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        40
        Synthesis of Chiral 3-Substituted Phthalides by a Sequential Organocatalytic Enantioselective Aldol-Lactonization Reaction. Three-Step Synthesis of (S)-(-)-3-Butylphthalide
        Zhang, Haoyi; Zhang, Shilei; Liu, Lu; Luo, Guangshun; Duan, Wenhu; Wang, Wei
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (2010), 75 (2), 368-374CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
        The development of efficient methods for the facile construction of important mol. frameworks is an important goal in org. synthesis. Chiral 3-substituted phthalides are widely distributed in a large collection of natural products with broad, potent, and potentially path-pointing biol. activities. In this investigation, an unprecedented organocatalytic asym. aldol-lactonization reaction of 2-formylbenzoic esters with ketones/aldehydes for convenient construction of the enantioenriched "privileged" scaffold was uncovered. As a result of the sensitive nature of substrate structures of an organocatalytic enantioselective aldol reaction, after extensive optimization of reaction conditions, catalyst L-prolinamide alc. I was identified as the best promoter. Interestingly, it was found that in this reaction, addn. of an acid additive PhCO2H can significantly enhance reaction efficiency with use of only as low as 2.5 mol % I for the process. Moreover, due to the sensitivity of reaction conditions toward a sequential aldol-lactonization process without affecting enantioselectivity and racemization, it is essential to remove the catalyst for the subsequent facile lactonization reaction in the presence of K2CO3. The aldol-lactonization processes serve as a powerful approach to the prepn. of synthetically and biol. important 3-substituted phthalides with a high level of enantioselectivities. A 3-step catalytic asym. synthesis of the natural product of (S)-(-)-3-butylphthalide (II) was reported.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsFGhtb%252FI&md5=d65aa9dd0bb5c853c48835b3558294cf

        Sedanenolide (3-butyl-4,5-dihydrophthalide) [63038-10-8] is a major phthalide component of celery seed essential oil. Basic hydrolysis of this odor compd. yields sedanonic acid [6697-07-0]. Sedanolide and sedanonic anhydride were not detected in celery seed.

        43
        Catalytic Asymmetric Conjugate Addition of Carboxylic Acids via Oxa-Michael Reaction of Peroxy Hemiacetals followed by Kornblum DeLaMare Fragmentation
        Parhi, Biswajit; Maity, Sanjay; Ghorai, Prasanta
        Organic Letters (2016), 18 (20), 5220-5223CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
        Disclosed herein an overall methodol. constitutes an equiv. to the long sought after enantioselective intramol. oxa-Michael (IOM) reaction of carboxylic acids. An organocatalyzed IOM reaction of in situ formed peroxy hemiacetals followed by a Kornblum DeLaMare type rearrangement cascade provides a broad class of chiral lactones in good yields and with excellent enantioselectivities. Remarkably, the pure chiral lactones are obtained without any silica gel column chromatog., and in many cases, the enantioselectivity is further increased by a simple hexane wash of the isolated solid products.

        Lu, B.; Zhao, M.; Ding, G.; Xie, X.; Jiang, L.; Ratovelomanana-Vidal, V.; Zhang, Z. Ruthenium-Catalyzed Enantioselective Hydrogenation/ Lactonization of 2-Acylarylcarboxylates: Direct Access to Chiral 3-Substituted Phthalides. ChemCatChem 2017, 9, 3989– 3996,  DOI: 10.1002/cctc.201700695

        Ruthenium-Catalyzed Enantioselective Hydrogenation/Lactonization of 2-Acylarylcarboxylates: Direct Access to Chiral 3-Substituted Phthalides
        Lu, Bin; Zhao, Mengmeng; Ding, Guangni; Xie, Xiaomin; Jiang, Lili; Ratovelomanana-Vidal, Virginie; Zhang, Zhaoguo
        ChemCatChem (2017), 9 (20), 3989-3996CODEN: CHEMK3; ISSN:1867-3880. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Highly enantioselective tandem hydrogenation/lactonization of various 2-acylarylcarboxylates including 2-aroylarylcarboxylates were realized by using [RuCl(benzene)(S)-SunPhos]Cl as the catalyst under mild reaction conditions. Excellent enantioselectivities (up to 99.6 % ee) and activities (S/C=1000) were obtained. This convenient and practical method enables a direct access to a series of highly optically pure 3-substituted phthalides I (R = Me, Et, n-Pr, Ph, etc.) that are very important mols. as valuable pharmacol. compds. and diversified synthons for medicinal chem. Moreover, a gram-scale reaction was performed to further demonstrate the practicality of this approach.

        Ir-SpinPHOX Catalyzed Enantioselective Hydrogenation of 3-Ylidenephthalides
        Ge, Yao; Han, Zhaobin; Wang, Zheng; Feng, Chen-Guo; Zhao, Qian; Lin, Guo-Qiang; Ding, Kuiling
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2018), 57 (40), 13140-13144CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The first asym. hydrogenation of 3-ylidenephthalides was developed using the IrI complex of a spiro[4,4]-1,6-nonadiene-based phosphine-oxazoline ligand (SpinPHOX) as the catalyst, affording a wide variety of chiral 3-substituted phthalides in excellent enantiomeric excesses (up to 98% ee). The utility of the protocol was demonstrated in the asym. synthesis of chiral drugs NBP and BZP precursor, as well as the natural products chuangxinol and typhaphthalide.

        Wang, Z.; Yao, N.; Fu, X.; Wei, L.; Ding, M.; Pang, Y.; Liu, D.; Ren, Y.; Guo, M. Butylphthalide Ameliorates Airway Inflammation and Mucus Hypersecretion via NF-κB in a Murine Asthma Model. Int. Immunopharmacol. 2019, 76, 105873,  DOI: 10.1016/j.intimp.2019.105873
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        46
        Butylphthalide ameliorates airway inflammation and mucus hypersecretion via NF-kappaB in a murine asthma model
        Wang, Zhiwang; Yao, Nan; Fu, Xiaoyan; Wei, Lingxia; Ding, Maopeng; Pang, Yarong; Liu, Dongling; Ren, Yuan; Guo, Mei
        International Immunopharmacology (2019), 76 (), 105873CODEN: IINMBA; ISSN:1567-5769. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Butylphthalide is a phthalide compd. contained in Angelicae Sinensis Radix which is one of the most widely used traditional Chinese medicines. This study aims to explore the therapeutic effect of NBP on airway inflammation, mucus hypersecretion and their possible mechanism in asthma mice. BALB/c mice were sensitized and challenged with ovalbumin for establishment of asthma model and then treated with NBP during day 22-77. The pulmonary function of the mice was detd., and the pathol. of lung tissue and goblet cell hyperplasia were obsd. through analyzing inflammation scores and goblet cell percentage, resp. Cytokine IL-4, IL-8, IL-13 and tumor necrosis factor-alpha in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid and total immunogloblin E and OVA-specific IgE in serum were examd. by ELISA. The expressions of Mucin 5AC and nuclear transcription factor-kappa B in lung tissues were evaluated by immunohistochem., western blot and real-time polymerase chain reaction . The results show that 50 mg/kg NBP significantly reduced OVA-induced increase in inflammation scoring, goblet cell percentage and mucus secretion of airway tissue, and improved the pulmonary function. NBP could also decrease IL-4, IL-8 IL-13, and TNF-α in BALF and T-IgE and OVA-specific IgE in serum. The expression of Muc5ac and NF-κB in lung tissue was significantly down-regulated after NBP treatment. This study suggested that NBP may effectively inhibit airway inflammation and mucus hypersecretion in asthma by modulating NF-κB activation.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhslWnt7fP&md5=3fe9ecc6e82a6e00f67d6e109d8fa6ef

        Geng, C.; Guo, Y.; Qiao, Y.; Zhang, J.; Chen, D.; Han, W.; Yang, M.; Jiang, P. UPLC-Q-TOF-MS Profiling of the Hippocampus Reveals Metabolite Biomarkers for the Impact of Dl-3-n-Butylphthalide on the Lipopolysaccharide Induced Rat Model of Depression. Neuropsychiatr. Dis. Treat. 2019, 15, 1939– 1950,  DOI: 10.2147/NDT.S203870
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        47
        UPLC-Q-TOF-MS profiling of the hippocampus reveals metabolite biomarkers for the impact of Dl-3-n-butylphthalide on the lipopolysaccharideinduced rat model of depression
        Geng, Chunmei; Guo, Yujin; Qiao, Yi; Zhang, Jun; Chen, Dan; Han, Wenxiu; Yang, Mengqi; Jiang, Pei
        Neuropsychiatric Disease and Treatment (2019), 15 (), 1939-1950CODEN: NDTEAZ; ISSN:1178-2021. (Dove Medical Press Ltd.)
        Purpose: An increasing body of evidence reveals that inflammation is involved in the pathol. mechanisms of depression. Our previous basic research confirmed that Dl-3-n-butylphthalide (NBP) possess anti-inflammatory properties. However, studies investigating metabolite biomarkers for the involvement of NBP in hippocampus tissue in the lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-induced rat model of depression are currently limited. Thus, the aim of this study was to identify metabolite biomarkers in the hippocampus for the impact of NBP in this model of depression. Material and methods: Male Sprague-Dawley rats were randomly allocated to one of the following three groups (n=6): Control, LPS-induced rat model of depression (LPS), and NBP involvement in the LPS-induced rat model of depression (LPS+NBP). Ultra-high-performance liq. chromatog.-mass spectroscopy was used to det. the hippocampal metabolites. Multivariate statistical anal. was performed to identify differentially expressed hippocampal metabolites in the three groups. Results: Most of the identified differentially expressed metabolites were related to amino acid, lipid, energy, and oxidative stress metab. Addnl., metabolites were eventually connected to different pathways and metabolic networks, which may partly account for the pathophysiol. process of depression. Conclusion: The present findings provide insight into the anti-inflammatory effects of NBP, and further elucidate the pathophysiol. mechanisms underlying inflammation-induced depression.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXksl2qurw%253D&md5=7b0115493b782f4366cfe7fdc3f17790

        Wang, W.; Wang, T.; Bai, S.; Chen, Z.; Qi, X.; Xie, P. Dl-3-n-Butylphthalide Attenuates Mouse Behavioral Deficits to Chronic Social Defeat Stress by Regulating Energy Metabolism via AKT/CREB Signaling Pathway. Transl. Psychiatry 2020, 10, 49,  DOI: 10.1038/s41398-020-0731-z
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        48
        Dl-3-n-butylphthalide attenuates mouse behavioral deficits to chronic social defeat stress by regulating energy metabolism via AKT/CREB signaling pathway
        Wang, Wei; Wang, Ting; Bai, Shunjie; Chen, Zhi; Qi, Xunzhong; Xie, Peng
        Translational Psychiatry (2020), 10 (1), 49CODEN: TPRSCF; ISSN:2158-3188. (Nature Research)
        Major depressive disorder (MDD) is a severe mental disorder assocd. with high rates of morbidity and mortality. Current first-line pharmacotherapies for MDD are based on enhancement of monoaminergic neurotransmission, but these antidepressants are still insufficient and produce significant side-effects. Dl-3-n-butylphthalide (NBP) is a compd. with proven efficacy in treating ischemic stroke, yet its therapeutic effects and mechanisms for depression remain unexplored. The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of NBP in a chronic social defeat stress model of depression and its underlying mol. mechanisms. Here, we examd. depression-related behavior and performed a targeted metabolomics anal. Real-time quant. polymerase chain reaction and western blotting were used to examine key genes and proteins involved in energy metab. and the AKT/cAMP response element-binding protein (CREB) signaling pathway. Our results reveal NBP attenuates stress-induced social deficits, anxiety-like behavior and despair behavior, and alters metabolite levels of glycolysis and tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle components. NBP affected gene expression of key enzymes of the TCA cycle, as well as protein expression of p-AKT and p-CREB. Our findings provide the first evidence showing that NBP can attenuate stress-induced behavioral deficits by modulating energy metab. by regulating activation of the AKT/CREB signaling pathway.

      50. 50
        Xu, D.-D.; Li, W.-T.; Jiang, D.; Wu, H.-G.; Ren, M.-S.; Wu, Y.-B.; Chen, M.-Q. 3-n-Butylphthalide Mitigates High Glucose-induced Injury to Schwann Cells: Association with Nitrosation and Apoptosis. Neural Regener. Res. 2019, 14, 513– 518,  DOI: 10.4103/1673-5374.245590
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        50
        3-N-Butylphthalide mitigates high glucose-induced injury to Schwann cells: association with nitrosation and apoptosis
        Xu Dan-Dan; Li Wen-Ting; Jiang Dan; Wu Huai-Guo; Ren Ming-Shan; Wu Yuan-Bo; Chen Mei-Qiao
        Neural regeneration research (2019), 14 (3), 513-518 ISSN:1673-5374.
        A high glucose state readily causes peripheral axon atrophy, demyelination, loss of nerve fiber function, and delayed regeneration. However, few studies have examined whether nitration is also critical for diabetic peripheral neuropathy. Therefore, this study investigated the effects of high glucose on proliferation, apoptosis, and 3-nitrotyrosine levels of Schwann cells treated with butylphthalide. In addition, we explored potential protective mechanisms of butylphthalide on peripheral nerves. Schwann cells were cultured in vitro with high glucose then stimulated with the peroxynitrite anion inhibitors uric acid and 3-n-butylphthalide for 48 hours. Cell Counting Kit-8 and flow cytometry were used to investigate the effects of uric acid and 3-n-butylphthalide on proliferation and apoptosis of Schwann cells exposed to a high glucose environment. Effects of uric acid and 3-n-butylphthalide on levels of 3-nitrotyrosine in Schwann cells were detected by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. The results indicated that Schwann cells cultured in high glucose showed decreased proliferation, but increased apoptosis and intracellular 3-nitrotyrosine levels. However, intervention with uric acid or 3-n-butylphthalide could increase proliferation of Schwann cells cultured in high glucose, and inhibited apoptosis and intracellular 3-nitrotyrosine levels. According to our data, 3-n-butylphthalide may inhibit cell nitrification and apoptosis, and promote cell proliferation, thereby reducing damage to Schwann cells caused by high glucose.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Wang, F.; Ma, J.; Han, F.; Guo, X.; Meng, L.; Sun, Y.; Jin, C.; Duan, H.; Li, H.; Peng, Y. DL-3-n-Butylphthalide Delays the Onset and Progression of Diabetic Cataract by Inhibiting Oxidative Stress in Rat Diabetic Model. Sci. Rep. 2016, 6, 19396,  DOI: 10.1038/srep19396
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        51
        DL-3-n-butylphthalide delays the onset and progression of diabetic cataract by inhibiting oxidative stress in rat diabetic model
        Wang, Fuxu; Ma, Jia; Han, Fei; Guo, Xiujin; Meng, Li; Sun, Yufeng; Jin, Cheng; Duan, Huijun; Li, Hang; Peng, Ying
        Scientific Reports (2016), 6 (), 19396CODEN: SRCEC3; ISSN:2045-2322. (Nature Publishing Group)
        DL-3-n-butylphthalide (NBP) is a therapeutic drug used for ischemic stroke treatment. Here, we investigated the impact of NBP on the development of rat diabetic cataract induced by i.p. injection of streptozotocin (STZ). NBP was then administrated by oral gavage for nine weeks. Cataract development was monitored through ophthalmoscope inspections. The levels of blood glucose and serum reactive oxygen species (ROS), malondialdehyde (MDA) and 8-Hydroxydeovexyguanosine (8-OHdG) were measured. Total and sol. protein and oxidative stress parameters, such as 2, 4- dinitrophenylhydrazone (DNP), 4-hydroxynonenal (4-HNE) and MDA in the lenses were detd. by Western blot and thiobarbituric acid analyses. The expressions of NF-E2-related factor 2 (Nrf2) and its downstream antioxidant enzymes, thioredoxin (TRX), Catalase and nuclear accumulation of Nrf2 were detd. by Western blot and immunohistochem. analyses. We showed that NBP treatment significantly improved the cataract scores, the levels of DNP, 4-HNE, and MDA in the lens compared to the non-treated groups. NBP also enhanced the expressions of Nrf2, TRX and catalase in the lens of diabetic rats. In addn., NBP treatment also decreased levels of blood glucose, serum MDA and 8-OHdG. These results suggested that NBP treatment significantly delayed the onset and progression of diabetic cataract by inhibiting the oxidative stresses.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xos1GktA%253D%253D&md5=8dab59369b27213beba98883f47a35a3

        Tian, Z.; Wang, J.; Wang, Y.; Zhang, M.; Zhou, Y. Effects of Butylphthalide on Cognitive Decline in Diabetic Rats. Mol. Med. Rep. 2017, 16, 9131– 9136,  DOI: 10.3892/mmr.2017.7700
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        52
        Effects of butylphthalide on cognitive decline in diabetic rats
        Tian, Zhiyan; Wang, Jinhua; Wang, Yan; Zhang, Miao; Zhou, Yuying
        Molecular Medicine Reports (2017), 16 (6), 9131-9136CODEN: MMROA5; ISSN:1791-3004. (Spandidos Publications Ltd.)
        Butylphthalide, a component extd. from seeds of Chinese celery, is an effective neuroprotective agent used for the treatment of ischemic stroke and dementia. Diabetes may cause central nervous system damage, and diabetes is closely assocd. with dementia. The aim of the present study was to investigate the effects of butylphthalide on cognitive impairment in a streptozotocin-induced diabetic rat model, and the underlying mechanisms of action. A total of 30 healthy male Sprague Dawley rats were randomly divided into the following 2 groups: Normal control (NC; n=10) and diabetes model (DM) groups (n=20). Diabetes was induced in rats in the DM group by i.p. injection of streptozotocin, and these rats were further subdivided into the following 2 groups: Diabetic control (n=10) and butylphthalide-treated groups (n=10). Following 8 consecutive weeks of treatment, a Morris water maze test was performed and the levels of blood fasting plasma glucose (FPG), superoxide dismutase (SOD), malondialdehyde (MDA) and tumor necrosis factor-α (TNF-α), interleukin (IL)-1β, and IL-6 inflammatory cytokines in the hippocampus were measured. FPG levels were significantly decreased in the butylphthalide-treated group when compared with the DM group. In addn., cognitive deficits in diabetic rats were improved following butylphthalide treatment. Furthermore, butylphthalide significantly increased the level of SOD, reduced MDA levels, and reduced TNF-α, IL-1β, and IL-6 levels in the hippocampus when compared with the DM group. The results of the present study suggest that butylphthalide may be an effective neuroprotective agent to improve cognitive dysfunction during diabetes.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhtl2ms7%252FM&md5=60d8f8413fe2c41b038993e2b100a565
      53. 53
        Li, J.; Zhang, S.; Zhang, L.; Wang, R.; Wang, M. Effects of L-3-n-Butylphthalide on Cognitive Dysfunction and NR2B Expression in Hippocampus of Streptozotocin (STZ)-Induced Diabetic Rats. Cell Biochem. Biophys. 2015, 71, 315– 322,  DOI: 10.1007/s12013-014-0200-5
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        53
        Effects of L-3-n-Butylphthalide on Cognitive Dysfunction and NR2B Expression in Hippocampus of Streptozotocin (STZ)-Induced Diabetic Rats
        Li, Jie; Zhang, Songyun; Zhang, Lihui; Wang, Ruiying; Wang, Mian
        Cell Biochemistry and Biophysics (2015), 71 (1), 315-322CODEN: CBBIFV; ISSN:1085-9195. (Springer)
        Diabetes mellitus is assocd. with rapid cognitive decline. Currently, there is no effective treatment for cognitive dysfunction induced by diabetes. L-3-n-Butylphthalide (L-NBP) is a nerve protective drug extd. from seeds of celery, which has been proved to improve learning and memory in vascular dementia animal models by improving microcirculation, protecting mitochondria and increasing long-term potentiation (LTP). NR2B, one of the subunits of N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor, has been proved to be an important factor for the formation of LTP. The study aimed to investigate the role of NR2B in cognitive dysfunction in the rats with type 1 diabetes and define the protective effects of L-NBP on cognition. A rat model of type 1 diabetes was established by a single i.p. injection of streptozotocin at 60 mg/kg. Animals were randomly allocated to four groups: normal control (NC); diabetic control (DC); diabetic + low L-NBP (DL, administered L-NBP 60 mg/kg per day for 12 wk); and diabetic + high L-NBP (DH, administered L-NBP 120 mg/kg per day, for 12 wk). After 12 wk, cognitive and memory changes were investigated in the Morris water maze. The expression of NR2B was assessed by real-time polymerase chain reaction, Western blotting, and immunohistochem. Our results indicated that the escape latency was significantly increased and the no. of crossing platform was significantly decreased in DC group compared to NC group. Also, the expression of NR2B was significantly declined in DC group. However, compared to DC group, the expression of NR2B of the L-NBP-treated groups was significantly increased and the escape latency was shortened with the DH group being the most obvious. Therefore, L-NBP can improve the cognitive function by up-regulating the expression of NR2B in STZ-diabetic rats, which may provide the direction for future diabetic encephalopathy therapy.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhsVekurfK&md5=da212e95cbc2f8094f63acb90864c357

        Zheng, B.; Zhou, Y.; Zhang, H.; Yang, G.; Hong, Z.; Han, D.; Wang, Q.; He, Z.; Liu, Y.; Wu, F.; Xie Zhang, X.; Tong, S.; Xu, H.; Xiao, J. Dl--3-n-Butylphthalide Prevents the Disruption of Blood-Spinal Cord Barrier via Inhibiting Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress Following Spinal Cord Injury. Int. J. Biol.         [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        54
        Dl-3-n-butylphthalide prevents the disruption of blood-spinal cord barrier via inhibiting endoplasmic reticulum stress following spinal cord injury
        Zheng, Binbin; Zhou, Yulong; Zhang, Hongyu; Yang, Guangyong; Hong, Zhenghua; Han, Dandan; Wang, Qingqing; He, Zili; Liu, Yanlong; Wu, Fenzan; Zhang, Xie; Tong, Songlin; Xu, Huazi; Xiao, Jian
        International Journal of Biological Sciences (2017), 13 (12), 1520-1531CODEN: IJBSB9; ISSN:1449-2288. (Ivyspring International Publisher)
        After spinal cord injury (SCI), the destruction of blood-spinal cord barrier (BSCB) is shown to accelerate gathering of noxious blood-derived components in the nervous system, leading to secondary neurodegenerative damages. SCI activates endoplasmic reticulum stress (ER stress), which is considered to evoke secondary damages of neurons and glia. Recent evidence indicates that Dl-3-n-butylphthalide (NBP) has the neuroprotective effect in ischemic brain injury, but whether it has protective effects on SCI or not is largely unclear. Here, we show that NBP prevented BSCB disruption after SCI via inhibition of ER stress. Following a moderate contusion injury of the T9 level of spinal cord, NBP was administered by oral gavage and further treated once a day. NBP significantly attenuated BSCB permeability and breakdown of adherens junction (AJ) and tight junction (TJ) proteins, then improved locomotion recovery following SCI. The protective role of NBP on BSCB disruption is assocd. with the restrain of ER stress caused by SCI. Furthermore, NBP considerably constrained the expression of ER stress-assocd. proteins and degrdn. of TJ and AJ in human brain microvascular endothelial cells (HBMECs) treated with TG. In conclusion, our results indicate that ER stress is assocd. with the disruption of BSCB integrity after injury, NBP attenuates BSCB disruption via inhibiting ER stress and improve functional recovery following SCI.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXitFemtrzK&md5=48ae1826b98eec136051fb9c064c03b8

Dl-3-n-Butylphthalide Improves Functional Recovery in Rats with Spinal Cord Injury by Inhibiting Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress-Induced Apoptosis. Am. J. Trans. Res. 2017, 9, 1075– 1087

        He, Z.; Zhou, Y.; Lin, L.; Wang, Q.; Khor, S.; Mao, Y.; Li, J.; Zhen, Z.; Chen, J.; Gao, Z.; Wu, F.; Zhang, X.; Zhan, H.; Xu, H.-Z.; Wang, Z.; Xiao, J.         Dl-3-n-butylphthalide attenuates acute inflammatory activation in rats with spinal cord injury by inhibiting microglial TLR4/NF-κB signalling
        He, Zili; Zhou, Yulong; Lin, Li; Wang, Qingqing; Khor, Sinan; Mao, Yuqin; Li, Jiawei; Zhen, Zengming; Chen, Jian; Gao, Zhenzhen; Wu, Fenzan; Zhang, Xie; Zhang, Hongyu; Xu, Hua-Zi; Wang, Zhouguang; Xiao, Jian
        Journal of Cellular and Molecular Medicine (2017), 21 (11), 3010-3022CODEN: JCMMC9; ISSN:1582-4934. (Wiley-Blackwell)
        In this study, we examd. the neuroprotective effects and anti-inflammatory properties of Dl-3-n-butylphthalide (NBP) in Sprague-Dawley (SD) rats following traumatic spinal cord injury (SCI) as well as microglia activation and inflammatory response both in vivo and in vitro. Our results showed that NBP improved the locomotor recovery of SD rats after SCI an significantly diminished the lesion cavity area of the spinal cord, apoptotic activity in neurons, and the no. of TUNEL-pos. cells at 7 days post-injury. NBP inhibited activation of microglia, diminished the release of inflammatory mediators, and reduced the upregulation of microglial TLR4/NF-κB expression at 1 day post-injury. In a co-culture system with BV-2 cells and PC12 cells, NBP significantly reduced the cytotoxicity of BV-2 cells following lipopolysaccharide (LPS) stimulation. In addn., NBP reduced the activation of BV-2 cells, diminished the release of inflammatory mediators, and inhibited microglial TLR4/NF-κB expression in BV-2 cells. Our findings demonstrate that NBP may have neuroprotective and anti-inflammatory properties in the treatment of SCI by inhibiting the activation of microglia via TLR4/NF-κB signalling.

        Sahib, S.; Tian, Z. R.; Niu, F.; Sharma, A.; Feng, L.; Muresanu, D. F.; Nozari, A.; Sharma, H. S. Potentiation of Spinal Cord Conduction and Neuroprotection Following Nanodelivery of DL-3-n-Butylphthalide in Titanium Implanted Nanomaterial in a Focal Spinal Cord Injury Induced Functional Outcome, Blood-spinal Cord Barrier Breakdown and Edema Formation. Int. Rev. Neurobiol. 2019, 146, 153– 188,  DOI: 10.1016/bs.irn.2019.06.009
